The work of Diary of a Cricket was signed in 1941 and is the excellent work of writer To Hoai writing for children. The story tells about the adventures, the experience of De Men and the lessons of life.
De Men used to live independently since childhood, when he became a robust young cricket boy, he was aggressive and arrogant, causing rebellious professionals to regret. Bored from living on the edge of the field, De Men traveled back and forth to open his eyes and find meaning for his life. De Men met with De Trui and ended up working side by side in the trips. Went through many places, encountered many species, saw many scenes of life, and also met many difficulties and dangers, but De Men did not give up. In the end, De Men and his friends realized that: "Everyone has kindness and everyone wants to do business in peace". They asked their friends to spread the word to invite all species to be brothers, warmly welcomed by the species.
Through the story the author raises questions about the discernment of good and evil, and advocacy for those weaker than themselves. Experiencing the life of De Men, the lessons that he learned from many dangerous dangers is the luggage for him to come into life. Therefore, it can be said that the life of De Men is a great lesson: â€œTravel broadens the mindâ€.
The lesson learned from that story is the courage, the inquisitive personality, the sacred friendship with De Trui that saved you from the danger that previously De Men had to regret not being able to do with De Choat. It is the experience of De Men that has cultivated the noble character that young people must learn. The adventure of De Men has also made friends with many people and with his friends against the injustices in society. Even if he previously made mistakes in the past, he still stands up to continue to correct his own mistakes and rise to useful life. (less)

3.5 stars

It was a very cute book, and the reason I bought it and read it makes it more special to me. I was working in Hanoi, Vietnam in April-May this year and asked my dear friend to take me to all the book stores in Hanoi (quite a lot!). Although I could have bought almost every single Vietnamese book (because the covers are gorgeous and I'm not really someone who buys based on cover only... especially not in languages I don't speak) but I was on a mission to find some Vietnamese authors in English.

I found one, and when I was about to pay for it, she picks up this one and says that it is a common fairy tale which she had read to her as a child. In English. With gorgeous illustrations. Said and done, i bought that one as well.

I don't know what it is, but I have a major problem with bugs. I like to pretend I don't, but it's getting harder to hide. So a lot of the illustrations of bugs sort of gave me anxiety. And I don't know why, I mean, it's not like there are real pictures of bugs!

But let's talk about the story, it really was an exiting adventure, and I loved how humble the Cricket was to learn from his mistakes. Sure, sometimes it was a bit down my throat with the message of peace (having one group claim universal peace can be more problematic than you think... I study for a master in humanitarian assistance in conflict, if there is one thing I have learned, NO ONE is spared from the possibility of doing more harm than good). But it was a fun read and I felt closer to my friends in Hanoi now being so far away. Okay so this was more like a diary entry than a review, but well you know what, that's the way it is sometimes.
(less)

So this was an enjoyable book about the journeys of a Cricket and the life lesson's he learns along the way. My wife says that she studied this at school and I can see why they would use this book as a study text. (This was of course the Vietnamese original and not the translation). My mother in law also read it as a child.

The translation appears to be in an older style of British English and there are one or two small typos but nothing major they are easily overlooked.

The story definitely includes a little propaganda towards the end. In my edition (an older copy), the notes in the afterward from the publishers said that there are parts of the book missing due to "ridiculous cuttings" by the colonisers at the time in 1942 which are now lost.

Honestly though, all of this didn't affect my enjoyment of the book and it spreads a good message to children about everyone learning to share and renounce warfare and violence. The characters are well written and the world building is well done considering the nature of this book.

I will recommend it to more people interested in translated Vietnamese stories. (less)

Five years ago, I read this book in Vietnamese and felt in love with the stories. This year, I found the English copy of it and read it again in English. The impression is still fresh like I'm reading it for the first time. Of course there were more subtle humors and emotional connotations in the Vietnamese version. After all, this is the original language of the book. But the English translation does not lose the stories' meanings and I still find myself enjoy every page of it.

On this second read, the stories come back with way more values that I failed to recognize before. I am in awe with the ways village folks care for each other. They can just drop whatever they're doing to take care of a neighbor in need. They can gather around a sad person to share and help her bare the emotional suffering. At the same time, the innocence of the kids are so precious to the grown-ups and the whole village's happiness is sustained by them. Tragedies of the adults are turned into the most valuable lessons for kids on love, compassion, and what it really means to be neighbors. In this, the village's best assets are not the material wealth or cash, their best assets are the fields and the people, especially the kids. They grow up understanding their world with all their five senses working. Everyone contributes his or her share to a kid's development in the most honest way there is. It's a genuine sense of community, so pure and lucid that I feel tears in my eyes.

On a side note, the English version still has some little typos here and there, but I manage to ignore them and they don't deteriorate the content of this book too much. (less)

This book was given to me as a gift by a student of mine when I left their school to move away. She said "It's my favourite book so I wanted to share it with you".

Two years later I finally found the time to read this and now I am blubbing like a baby. It's written in such a way that captures childhood innocence even through moments of sadness and grief. I read the whole thing in a day.

There are some jarring cultural differences early on in what is considered acceptable between Vietnamese and Western society. However, if you go into this with a little knowledge of Vietnamese culture and accept it for what it is, you will find a heartwarming and moving story of a young boy learning about life through his relationships with the people in his village.

Finishing the book left me with that indescribable feeling of gratitude for the story and sadness that it was over. It ended strong and bittersweet. I may very well re-read this in the future. (less)

This book is rightly regarded as the Vietnamese "Little Prince."
Nguyen Ngoc Thuan chose the approach of describing things in great attentiveness through untainted views of a little boy, all the while making sure that such an approach does justice to the uniqueness of his view of the world around without sounding overly naive. He employs various rhetorical techniques, so masterfully yet subtly skillful ones that on reading it, a child reader can still relate and an adult reader can still appreciate.
It deals with childhood traumas, with death, with love and how to love. It equips the reader yet again with the tools to resolve his own childhood trauma, his own encountering with death and love. It preaches about love. The book holds a healing power.
I'd recommend this book to anyone.
(less)

A book for kids but also give so many precious lessons for adults. The writing way of the author is simple with the innocence from the character but that is so wonderful when it can touch my heart easily. Sometime in this hustle and bustle life, calm down, close your eyes and feel our life through imagination , touches and smells we can feel the life more enjoyably. Being an adult or a teenager doesn't mean that we stop learning, this time give time to read this book and that is how we can learn from the kids. I love a comment behind the book that in this life we need a place to recharge, slow down, think slowly about something and take energy to continue the journey so this book is a place like that. How touching these stories are!

Kien is a survivor of the Viet Nam war, a North Vietnamese survivor. This book is written by a North Vietnamese writer and clearly evokes much of his experience in what was a much longer war for the Vietnamese than it was for Americans. The similarities between the affects of war on all sides are clear, but this tale is uniquely home grown. The story is told in several different time lines. Kien recalls his youth, his early years in the military, a time ten years after he entered the war, events later in the war, the period at its conclusion and a thread in what is the character's contemporary post-war. His central relationship is with his childhood sweetheart Phuong (and one wonders here whether the name is merely a very common Vietnamese given name or if there might be an echo of The Quiet American at play here). As the title indicates, sorrow is a central feature of the story. Kienâ€™s nickname means â€œSorrowful Spirit.â€ And war is certainly a rich cornucopia of grief.


Báº£o Ninh- Image from VanHocSaigon.com

Kien recalls a parade of figures from his personal history, family members, people from his neighborhood, his first awakening of sexual feelings. Virtually all of his comrades in arms were killed. There is one killing field in particular that chills him. Called â€œThe Jungle of Screaming Souls,â€ it was a place where his battalion was massacred, Kien being one of only ten who had survived. and by the post-war, the only one left alive. His post-war work of travelling the nation attempting to identify the remains of the thousands of unmarked dead so that their families could get closure keeps him close to the ghosts of those who had passed. Yes, he sees ghosts. They are legion, and it appears to be his lot to see them and attempt to bring them some peace. Sometimes there is nothing he can do but be a witness to them.

The many characters are interesting and engaging if short-lived. Lofty Thinh was a soldier who had slain an orang. And when the company saw the corpse they were freaked out at how closely it resembled a woman. Can was a deserter who died alone in the jungle. Hanh was a beauty of his hometown, the object of every manâ€™s desire, who offered herself to him when he was a lad, an act that terrified more than titillated him. Green Coffee Girl was the sister of a friend of his from childhood, a hooker as an adult. Kien saved her from an assault. Hoa was an inept 19-year old female guide who sacrificed herself so the troop she was attempting to lead to safety could avoid being killed by an American search and destroy team.

There is much back and forth among the timelines. It takes some attention to remain focused, but this is a marvelous book, a very human tale that explores a soldierâ€™s relationship with his past, his relationships with those around him, his role in the world, how the war affected him and his society. While Ninh offers a truly Vietnamese perspective, the disdain of the ordinary people for political leaders is just as palpable as any Americanâ€™s disgust with many of our leaders. Kien lives in a world alive with the ghosts of memory and what soldier does not? Ninhâ€™s imagery is rich, his characters engaging and interesting, and the central pillar of the narrative, Kienâ€™s relationship with Phuong, while frequently muted by other events, holds well enough as an organizational mechanism. There is also much in here about writing. It was clear that this was a difficult book for Ninh to write and he reflects on the process in the novel itself. While it is not at a level with true literary giants, this is a very nice read, a wonderful first book by a gifted writer. I hope to find more by him.

The Future Lied To Us

A reminiscence, rather than a memoir, tumbling between the time before war, eleven years of brutal fighting, and then its aftermath. Shifting from first to third person, with the occasional second person letter, the story is as unstructured as the lives involved. And none of it is politically correct: â€œNo. The ones who loved war were not the young men, but the others like the politicians, middle-aged men with fat bellies and short legs. Not the ordinary people. The recent years of war had brought enough suffering and pain to last them a thousand years.â€

At its simplest, this story is the universal one of the common soldier: an inexperienced young man dislocated from a normal life, and exposed to the horror of having to kill and watching others killed, seemingly endlessly. Inevitably he loses not only his civilized existence but his identity. Using drugs when he can find them and pure grit when he canâ€™t, he manages to survive. But for what? His peace is as a worn out alcoholic, all his family, friends, and comrades dead. Unable to sustain any sort of intimate relationship, all he can do is remember. â€œThis kind of peace? In this kind of peace it seems people have unmasked themselves and revealed their true, horrible selves. So much blood, so many lives were sacrificed for what?â€ His memory, particularly his memory of his own expectations, is the source of his malaise.

He writes as a form of therapy, to rid himself of the devils, his memories, that now constitute his personality. All he has is these devils, these ghosts, who appear in flashbacks, spontaneous violence, recurrent dreams of disaster and a depressive lethargy. Only by writing about them can he exorcise their power. He has been told by others who have been in his position, â€œAfter this hard-won victory fighters like you, Kien, will never be normal again. You wonâ€™t even speak with your normal voice, in the normal way again.â€

So his challenge is to find a new voice, actually an entirely new personality represented by such a voice. Some voice other than â€œThe way you speak in hell.â€ Incrementally he is able to find himself without forgetting what he has seen: â€œThe tragedies of the war years have bequeathed to my soul the spiritual strength that allows me to escape the infinite present. The little trust and will to live that remains stems not from my illusions but from the power of my recall.â€ He realises that there is something within him waiting to be made visible: â€œThere is a force at work in him that he cannot resist, as though it opposes every orthodox attitude taught him and it is now his task to expose the realities of war and to tear aside conventional images.â€

This force reveals hard truths known to every common soldier in every war of history: â€œWhat remained was sorrow, the immense sorrow, the sorrow of having survived. The sorrow of war.â€ The only real result is sorrow, â€œJustice may have won, but cruelty, death and inhuman violence had also won... Losses can be made good, damage can be repaired and wounds will heal in time. But the psychological scars of the war will remain forever.â€

And yet despite the unequal balance of cost and benefit, there is something else, a â€œspiritual beauty in the horrors of conflict,â€ without which â€œthe war would have been another brutal, sadistic exercise.â€ Throughout his story Bao Ninh weaves a sort of lyrical spirituality which would be an obscenity if written by anyone who hadnâ€™t been through the grinding mill of virtually the entire American War in Vietnam. â€œHe saw his life as a river with himself standing unsteadily at the peak of a tall hill, silently watching his life ebb from him, saying farewell to himself. Eventually he emerges from the nihilism of his despair in the reading of his manuscript by another who, through it, feels he knows the author: â€œHis spirit had not been eroded by a cloudy memory. This is a book that every veteran who saw combat in Vietnam should read. It gives the other side and points up so poignantly the universal suffering of all soldiers. It helped me to come to an understanding that none of the anger and resentment I feel about my service in Indochina had anything to do with those we called the enemy but towards those who put us where we were;who trained us to fight and steel our hearts towards those who were always referred to as "gooks, dinks, or nogs";those who cynically betrayed us over and over again from beginning to end and who continue to betray us as they seek to limit what they must give in compensation for wounds suffered, physical and mental,to keep their position, their benefits their reputations and what they see as their rightful slice of "the pie". They try to gloss over the depth of their betrayal and their absolute lack of morality with fine words about the flag and sacrifice and tradition and by passing out a few more medals 40 years too late but they fail to understand the depth and breadth of the impact of their actions, then and now. Bastards; may they rot in hell! I feel much more for the enemies they set up for us, more compassion, more in common with them. I wish with the same breath that I use to curse our politicians to hell, that those who were my enemy may rest or live in peace. (less)

As the title makes clear, this is not a book you can read without some real emotional work; Bao Ninh, pen name of a North Vietnamese veteran, barely mentions the invading Americans, except in a few searing passages that come through with a cinematic calm and vividness. His overall subject is what war does to the people who fight it, and the novel is in part about the writing of the novel, the kind of approach that usually fails, at least in my estimation, but here works oddly well. It helps to establish the mood of reluctant truth telling, since either way, telling the truth or not, there's no hope left, no beauty left, only whatever refracted glow might remain from peering into the joys of the distant past. A wonderful novel about the struggle to live with the knowledge that one has survived. The biography of the author in my copy states, "he served with the Glorious 27th Youth Brigade. Of the five hundred who went to war with the brigade in 1969, he is one of ten who survived."

But this isn't a memoir, though it obviously draws on the author's experiences. It's a novel, told in the third person and focusing on the experiences of Kien. It begins after the war is over, as the "Missing In Action body-collecting team awaits the dry season of 1976," and circles back and back to the battles in which Kien fought, the brutality he witnessed, the sacrifices of [the guide] "Hoa and countless other loved comrades, nameless ordinary soldiers" that saved Kien's life, to his childhood and youth in Hanoi, and his struggles to write this novel in the postwar period.

His experience of having survived against the odds, not because he was a better soldier, or braver than others, but simply by chance, good fortune, reminds one of Primo Levi, who also suffered from the immense burden of having survived, of knowing that
the kindest, most worthy people have all fallen away, or even been tortured, humiliated before being killed, or buried and wiped away by the machinery of war.... Justice may have won, but cruelty, death and inhuman violence had also won.
What remained was sorrow, the immense sorrow, the sorrow of having survived. (p.187)
Kien's great love Phuong comes and goes throughout the novel. I have to say I found her incoherent as a character and began to wonder if she is actually standing in for Vietnam itself--beautiful and ravaged, faithful and inconstant, innocent and corrupt.

I need to read more work by Vietnamese writers. (less)

The sorrow of war inside a soldierâ€™s heart was in a strange way similar to the sorrow of love. It was a kind of nostalgia, like the immense sadness of a world at dusk. It was a sadness, a missing, a pain which could send one soaring back into the past. The sorrow of the battlefield could not normally be pinpointed to one particular event, or even one person. If you focused on any one event it would soon become a tearing pain.

The next book in my project to read all the past winners of the Independent Foreign Fiction Prize (now the Man Booker International) takes me to 1994 and The Sorrow of War.

It won from a shortlist of; The Following Story by Cees Nooteboom, translated by Ina Rilke; Fima by Amos Oz, translated by Nicholas de Lange; The Moment Between the Past and the Future, by Grigorij Baklanov, translated by Catherine Porter; The Road to San Giovanni by Italo Calvino, translated by Tim Parks and The Infinite Plan by Isabel Allende, translated by Margaret Sayers Peden.

Báº£o Nin's Vietnamese original ThÃ¢n pháº­n cá»§a tÃ¬nh yÃªu (English: The Destiny of Love) was circulated in mimeographed form. Phan Thanh Hao translated it into English and brought it to the attention of a London publisher, who then commissioned journalist and translator Frank Patmos to prepare this final English version.

The judges citation stated (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk... "The Sorrow of War is both remarkable and historic. Usually, history is the story told by the winners; Bao Ninh's book reminds us that, in war, everybody loses."

The novel tells the story of Kien, who fights throughout the Vietnamese war, on the ultimate victorious North Vietnamese side. But as the title suggests, this is certainly not a novel that glorifies war, nor is it one that tries to tell the story of the wider conflict, focusing on the personal impact on the soldiers who fought:

Iâ€™m nearly forty. I was eighteen at the start of the war in 1965, twenty-eight at the fall of Saigon in 1975. So, how many long years have passed? Ten or eleven? Twelve. No. Thirteen? Another year with the MIA team. Or was it longer? And more time wandering as a Veteran. Closer to fourteen years lost because of the war.

The author himself fought through the Vietnam War, although he was older at 27 when called up in 1969. Kien's younger age enables the book to more effectively show the stripping away of his innocence, he and his 17 year-old girlfriend Phuong virgins as the conflict begins. This loss of innocence takes place rapidly, in the first few days before he has even reached the front (although the story is only told late in the novel):

We were born pure and innocent. Look how innocent we are now,â€™ she mumbled. He could hardly miss the allusion to their new status as multiple rape victim and brutal murderer.

Kien is a survivor, ultimately the only one of his brigade to do so, reflecting the author's own experience as one of only 10 out of 500 of his brigade to make it through the war.

At the front, among the dead and surrounded by suffering, he often dreamed of and really felt her warm flesh again and tasted her virgin milk; in his dreams it was that which had given him the magical vitality to become the strongest, the luckiest, the greatest survivor of the war.

The literary strength of the novel comes from the way it is told. This is far from a linear account. It opens with Kien retrieving bodies after the conflict has ended:

on the banks of the Ya Crong Poco River, on the northern flank of the B3 battlefield in the Central Highlands, the Missing In Action body-collecting team awaits the dry season of 1976.

By 40 Kien is a "famous author" but one who is now trying, for cathartic as much as literary purposes, to write the story of his war. The account he writes refuses to follow a simple linear structure, circling back and forth through time:

When starting this novel, the first in his life, he planned a post-war plot. He started by writing about the MIA Remains-Gathering team, those about-to-be-demobilised soldiers on the verge of returning to ordinary civilian life. But relentlessly, his pen disobeyed him. Each page revived one story of death after another and gradually the stories swirled back deep into the primitive jungles of war, quietly re-stoking his horrible furnace of war memories.
...
The memory that afternoon reawakened in him the sense of sacred duty. He felt he must press on to fulfil his obligations, his duty as a writer. It was necessary to write about the war, to touch readersâ€™ hearts, to move them with words of love and sorrow, to bring to life the electric moments, to let them, in the reading and the telling, feel they were there, in the past, with the author. Why choose war? Why must he write of the war? His life and that of so many others was so horrible it could hardly be called a life. How can one find artistic recognition in that kind of life?
...
He dares not abandon himself to emotions, yet in each chapter Kien writes of the war in a deeply personal way, as though it had been his very own war. And so on and on, frantically writing, Kien refights all his battles, relives the times where his life was bitter, lonely, surreal, and full of obstacles and horrendous mistakes. There is a force at work in him that he cannot resist, as though it opposes every orthodox attitude taught him and it is now his task to expose the realities of war and to tear aside conventional images. It is a dangerous spin he is in, flying off at a tangent, away from the traditional descriptive writing styles, where everything is orderly. Kienâ€™s heroes are not the usual predictable, stiff figures but real people whose lives take diverse and unexpected directions.

In the novel we are reading, this is given an added (and perhaps unnecessary) metafictional touch in that in part we are reading Kien's account and in part commentary on it by someone who found the pages, themselves jumbled, and is trying to reassemble the story:

At first I tried to rearrange the manuscript pages into chronological order, to make the manuscript read like the sort of book I was familiar with. But it was useless. There was no chronological order at all. Any page seemed like the first, any page could have been the last. Even if the manuscript had been numbered, even if no pages had been burned, or moth-eaten, or withheld by the author, if by chance they were all there, this novel would still be a work created by turbulent, even manic inspirations.

Although much of Kien's tale is of the brutal reality of war, the futility and the suffering, he does bring out the heroism of others who sacrificed themselves - although he sees these sacrifices as personal, to save their friends, rather than in the furtherance of the cause of those who commissioned the conflict:

But for Hoa and countless other loved comrades, nameless ordinary soldiers, those who sacrificed for others and for their Vietnam, raising the name of Vietnam high and proud, creating a spiritual beauty in the horrors of conflict, the war would have been another brutal, sadistic exercise.

To win, martyrs had sacrificed their lives in order that others might survive. Not a new phenomenon, true. But for those still living to know that the kindest, most worthy people have all fallen away, or even been tortured, humiliated before being killed, or buried and wiped away by the machinery of war, then this beautiful landscape of calm and peace is an appalling paradox. Justice may have won, but cruelty, death and inhuman violence had also won.

And at a personal level, the impact of the conflict is shown on the relationship between Kien and Phuong, each so changed by the war that when they come together again they are essentially different people: Kien says he has only had two loves in his life: Phuong at seventeen in the pre-war days, and Phuong now, after the war but in practice, the changes to each are too much to enable their relationship to survive.

At a purely personal level this didn't quite work for me. Part of the fame the book has achieved has come in Vietnam from the honesty of an account that doesn't present the war as an triumphant heroic victory, and in the US from people being able to read an account from the other side, and see that much of their experience was shared. It must be said to me as a UK reader, where the Vietnamese war was much less of a epoch-defining event, these aspects were rather less powerful. And as mentioned, the meta-fictional aspects of the novel felt a little overdone, even though I normally like this sort of approach in a novel.

Nevertheless a worthwhile winner of a wonderful literary prize. 3.5 stars (less)

A short book about the horrors of war. It appealed because I wanted to read something from the Vietnamese viewpoint.

The protagonist is a survivor - most of his comrades so not make it through the war, and his life after the war is profoundly affected.

The book builds to a horrific event early on in its chronology, which is really sickening but goes a long way to explaining the nihilistic world view of some of the characters. Well worth a read.

At the end of the text, the author writes, â€œMany would say this was a disruption of the plot, a disconnection, a loss of perspective. Theyâ€™d say this style proved the writerâ€™s inherent weakness: his spirit was willing but his flesh wasnâ€™t.â€ (Ninh 230) The novel reads like memories scattered on pages; like diary pages ripped out, shuffled, and sewn together into a story. It has been said that art is either revolution or plagiarism. Bao Ninh certainly takes risk with his writing style, eliminating the classical features of rising action, climax, and so forth. With that being said, this novel is one that Ninh writes for himself, not for the reader. As for the glorified feature of the Northern perspective, there isnâ€™t anything truly fresh about this. Perhaps for some Americans who think that the North Vietnamese are evil , slimy, communists, this book would truly be enlightening, but for most the revelation that North Vietnamese communists are human too will seem rather obvious. But this is more of a grievance with some reviews, and not with the author or the novel. Iâ€™m still torn with this novel; so much of my opinion depends upon whether certain elements were intentional or flaws in writing. Throughout the entirety of the novel, Ninh creates a generally nostalgic tone. Sometimes it is to the point of despair, sometimes mere malaise. It is rather overwhelming to be bombarded with the same mood throughout the entire novel. Perhaps Ninh did this intentionally to portray the reality of the world seen through the eyes of Kien. But I find it to be limiting of the storytelling. Another element I found to be distracting was Ninhâ€™s use of the supernatural. Ninh includes ghosts, spirits, and screaming jungles to comment on the dead, but they have a limited effect. Iâ€™m sure another author may have been able to use these elements efficiently, but Ninhâ€™s use is rather distracting to the story and flow of time (or lack thereof). In fact, I observed that Ninh ever rarely captivated me with his language. I discussed with a friend that writers like Annie Dillard can make looking out the window as a child seem utterly profound, while Bao Ninh seems to have difficulty making even the most significant of circumstances important. But to Ninhâ€™s credit, I found one description of Kien and Phuongâ€™s love rather amusing: â€œ[Kienâ€™s:] loneliness pierced [Phuong:] like a knife, throbbing painfully.â€ (Ninh 115) But other than that, I was less than awed. Perhaps, it was the translation. Works in Spanish, for example, are relatively easy to translate into English, but other languages may not be so. Russian, in particular, is difficult. Perhaps, some of the novelâ€™s power is lost in the translation. There are a few beautiful pieces of prose within The Sorrow of War, but they are limited to a few passages. I felt the ending was stronger than the rest of the novel. In fact, it could have been much better if it had been shortened. The way it stands now is just too long for what it says. I really wanted to fall in love with this book, but the writing style made it impossible for me. If youâ€™re looking for a good Vietnam novel, read The Things They Carried by Tim Oâ€™Brien. Strangely enough, they both novels are set up in vignette styled stories, but Oâ€™Brien has the talent to pull it off. Do I recommend this novel? Not over many others. But it has some redeemable qualities and some readers, Iâ€™m sure, will find his writing style to suit them. (less)

"The novel was the ash from this exorcism of devils."

At all turns a tremendous and ghastly novel of war and most especially its aftermath. This might very well be the best "war" novel I've ever read, though it is far more about piecing together one's experience in war and trying to sift through it for a sign of how one should go on.
Kien is the thinly-disguised author who, I'm assuming, drew off his own horrific experience over the decade of the Vietnam War, as a soldier from the North. Kien remembers terrifying and often gory goings-on on the battlefield while struggling to cope with peace, all the while wondering if it was worth it. In a telling touch, Kien is also a novelist.

As a soldier who did a 14 month tour in Vietnam and 14 plus years active duty, I hardly know where to begin the review this book. I graduated from high school in 1965, joining the Army a year later. This is the story of Bao Kien, a North Vietnamese soldier and my enemy. When he was 17, in 1965, just graduated rom high school in Hanoi, he was conscripted to the Glorius 27th Youth Brigade in the North Vietnamese Army. The author writes transparently, making it difficult to tell which is fiction and which is auto-biography.

In writing this apparent memoir, Bao writes that "writing is the last effort of a soldier, to tell the story of war." For Bao, each page, written over a period of nearly 20 years after the end of the war, revived one story of death after another. Bao writes to rid himself of his devils. After eleven years of service, when the ARVN were defeated on April 30, 1975, in his advanced scout Platoon, he was the sole survivor.

Where my tour was pre-determined, a finite 13 months, Kien's was date uncertain, infinite. How long, he ponders? Five years? 10? 20? The duration? His tour was filled with jungles, swamps, mud and leeches, just like mine. Coming from a culture of superstitions, his was filled with ghosts, spirits, incense, smoke, bullets, bombs and uncertainty, the only certainty, in his eyes and experience, being death. The period 1968-69 was his worst nightmare. Of the 500 men in his Battalion 27 who went to battle against the Americans in the Central Highlands, during the dry season of 1969, Kien was one of only ten who survived the battle. Coincidentally, the same period was the worst for American casualties.

Whomp! Whomp! Whomp! A comforting sound to every GI. Here comes the cavalry! Hot food, water, mail, more ammo, reinforcements, dust off for wounded, a ride home. For Kien, the sound of dread: bullets, rockets and certain death, second only to the relentless artillery and air barrage.

Unlike many American-written books and movies that emphasize the blood, guts and glory of war, Bao only relates a few battles and personally poignant deaths, he preferring to emphasize the overall trauma of war. In his words, "Losses can be made good, damage can be repaired and wounds will heal in time, but the psychological scars of the war will remain forever." "The spirits of all those killed in the war will remain beyond all political consequences of the war," writes Bao, as he questions the "why" of the war. He describes the fall of Saigon on April 30, not as a joyous victory and a celebration of the end of the war, but a surreal apocalypse as soldiers became madmen, killing wantonly and looting for souvenirs. There was no glory, no trumpets for their victorious soldiers returning home. Returning to Hanoi on the troop train, Kien found no fanfair, no utopian dream of gloriously returning to Phoung, his childhood sweetheart. Over eleven years of war, they had both changed, drifted apart and there was a new "Jody" in the picture. After the war, Kien only found emptiness and utter isolation. War was all he knew, there being no job for which him to return. Trying to escape his ghosts, devils and nightmares, there is nowhere for him to turn, his friends all killed in the war, his family all gone. He turns to alcohol and, ultimately, to his writing. He struggles with the lack of a future and prefers to live in the past, in spite of the pain found there, the never-ending past, Bao's story of loyalty, friendship, brotherhood, comradeship and humanity.

I have met mine enemy . . . and he is us. Bao, thank you for writing your story. My salute and my respect. (less)

heartbreaking and deep

Kien became a writer to try to piece his life together, though, he continued to experience "...similar, even identical moments, long periods of withdrawal. Like the dead, one felt no fear, no enthusiasm, no joy, no sadness, no feelings for anything. No concerns and no hopes. One was totally devoid of feeling and had no regard for the clever or the stupid, the brave or the cowardly, commanders r privates, friend or foe, life or death, happiness or sadness. It was all the same; it amounted to nothing."

He writes because he must...and what he writes is this book.

War changes everything: the way one thinks, the way one remembers, who one is, who others are, who one was, who they were, how it was, how it is...and then there are the ghosts, not only of comrades and friends, but those who would have been what if their lives had not been changed by war.

Kien was a soldier. Then, he worked to retrieve bodies and have them identified so that their families could re-bury them with their ancestors. Then, he searched for himself and for the world, now so very different from what it had once been, now a world where ghosts hold his being in their hands, in their cries.

This is a brilliant and beautiful book about humanity and the power of the narratives that explode in people's minds. Not to be missed.

A book written about the Vietnam war from the perspective of a North Vietnamese solider. The book is brutal in the futility and arbitrariness of fate. He is one of a few survivors from his battalion.

The innocence of his childhood and the insanity of the war is wonderfully described. A novella well worth reading and I can understand why it won the independent foreign fiction award. (less)

War is not fun. For a detailed account of just how complicatedly unfun war gets, read this book. It is not fun, the title says as much, but life gets that way for a lot of unfortunate people who are just born on the wrong side of a shitstorm, and very few get to survive and even tell the tale in a sublimely meaningful way.
Bao Ninh's book is a sensitive, unflinching and relentless venture, coming to terms with what most readers will hopefully not recognize as their own life. This is a strenuous read, well-translated into English by Phan Thanh Hao, and nothing like any other war books I've read - although in many ways reminiscent of many real-life survivor accounts. A markedly romantic approach to narration is counterpointed with meticulous composition and unquestionable authenticity. A highly respectable work, worthy of international attention. (less)

This is one of the best books I've ever read (and yes, I know, I say that a lot).

I am shocked by reviews from readers being "Vietnamed out" when they read this. I mean, it's from the perspective of an NVA soldier. Maybe we should all read more books by North Vietnamese authors. It's not like it glorified the war or demonized Americans and the ARVN. It was completely refreshing to me.

When I started this book, I had just read a book from the American perspective of the Vietnam War. Some of the American soldiers, of course, had no idea what the hell they were doing there and wanted out. The same was true for so many NVA soldiers. I mean, we know this, that the NVA were human beings. But it just feels so good to read about NVA soldiers busy being human. It feels good to see that as idiotic as the war was, we all have the same worries and wants.

Some things that stuck with me:

1. There is a part of this book where Kien sees an American patrol and he is absolutely terrified. From his point of view, the Americans are as "other" as he is to them.

2. As awful as we like to imagine war is, our perception is nowhere as awful as it is for someone like Kien (and most veterans for that matter). Coronavirus doesn't even come close to eleven years of military service in a civil war.

3. The ARVN are much more present in this book than in most America-centric Vietnam War books, which was also enlivened my reading experience. This and the fact that many NVA troops could not have cared less about their government's ideology, including the ones who volunteered. (This is partly why Báº£o Ninh has been quite unpopular with the Vietnamese government.)

4. The NVA troops weren't all brainwashed communists or something. They weren't blind and deaf. They knew what their government was doing.

5. There are so many good people out there, and also so many people who would turn to animals and destroy your life the first chance they got. War has a way of warping you even when you have good intentions. For example, in one part of the book, Kien gets upset at his guide, who is quite young, because she accidentally gets his platoon lost.

6. There is a part of the book where Kien considers deserting to be with his sort-of girlfriend. However, he knows he will be shot as a deserter if he doesn't report to his - okay never mind. I don't know. I don't even know what I'm writing right now. I was going to just copy paste all the notes I took, but it would all be out of context. Basically this book is one giant nightmare in book form. It is about one more person's experience with war and hardship.

Which is exactly why you should read it.

as fascinating as this novel is, i can't help feeling a bit disappointed with it now that i'm finished. to my western eyes, it's pretty unique - a diaristic, plot-less account of a north vietnamese soldier's hardships during a war i'm well-versed in seeing from the opposite perspective. i'm a bit ashamed to admit this, but i don't think i've ever read a vietnamese novel before, so the fact that a few areas didn't resonate with me may reflect my own ignorance about the culture the novel comes from.

the protagonist (kien) spends the majority of the book fluctuating between shell-shocked depression and bitter nostalgia. time shifts rapidly in the book, and i enjoyed the challenge of keeping up with the shifts. structurally, this deepens the individual memories and adds considerable weight to the book's conclusion.

on the other hand, there's an ever-present dichotomy between purity and impurity that i found to be a big limitation. kien isn't so much a character as a vessel for the novel's bleak worldview and cynicism about war and political conflict. he longs for an idealized past that the novel too often takes for granted - particularly during the encounters with his childhood sweetheart phoung, who also seems to be more of a symbol than a person. at times, this works well - especially when counter-balanced by the more draconian elements of communist orthodoxy (i.e. the "three don'ts," which forbid young people from the pleasures of sex, love and marriage). but the rigid binaries between peace and conflict become repetitive and affect-less at times. some of the novel's darker passages begin to seem inevitable, and (at times) lose a bit of their impact as the narrative progresses. This is a powerful novel about the war in Viet Nam written by a soldier from North Viet Nam. In some ways, it resonates with the powerful novels about the war written by American GIs -- traumatic flashbacks, PTSD, desperate solutions through alcohol and rage -- but, of course, it is profoundly different because the war takes place in his homeland and affects his family, his lover, the land and everyone around him so deeply. The main character, Kien, is also writing a novel about his war experience -- or maybe not a novel, maybe just jumbled memories, non-chronological battle scenes, jottings about childhood -- in a bleak room in a shambling, almost-empty apartment building in Hanoi after the war. There are no chapters because the random papers, abandoned and blown about in a storm, are pieced together by the woman upstairs who finds them. Characters appear and reappear, even after we know they have been killed in battle as most of Kien't comrades were. Most memorable is his childhood love Phuong, whom he loses when the Americans bomb the freight train they are riding. When he finds her again, it turns out that -- though they are both alive -- neither of them have survived in tact. Beautifully written, definitely sorrowful.
(less)

I've never been less excited about having to teach a book.
Maybe I've just been lucky thus far.

I read this book specifically for the Works in Translation part of the IB course. Outside of that, I would not choose to read Sorrow of War: I'm not a reader of life writing, because I don't believe that an interesting life necessarily ensures a 'good' story.

I 'get' what the author is doing here, and I 'get' why it's important - Sorrow of War presents the 'other side' to a tale we too frequently dismiss in the West. As an Australian reader, I know that we don't even talk about the Vietnam War from 'our' perspective, because it was such a violent and bloody mistake. So yes, hearing the other side is certainly important for a range of reasons.

But it's not a novel that I enjoyed.

Kien, for all he has seen, is just not an interesting or likeable character. And I could roll with that if war had changed him, but I didn't see much to like in his characterisation before the war either. He's not particularly intelligent, or insightful, or even just interesting, which makes his descent into alcohol fuelled depression seem rather insignificant. Again, I get it - war hurts even the boring people, but as a protagonist, he seems like a weird choice to garner sympathy.

His relationship with Phuong completely did my head in. He was attracted to her because she was a beautiful free spirit, but then seemed to resent that in her at the same time. His instinctual misogyny was reflected in their sexual interactions (view spoiler) Sure, it's all pretty traumatic at that point, but that kind of derogatory reaction to the woman you love is a little off, in my books. It was an attitude which he extended to most of the women in the book - they were whores on the periphery of his tale (though one got close enough to give him VD?) or scorned for their inconsistency (in the case of both Phuong and his mother - some Freudian issues there maybe?)

However, the thing that really prevented me from connecting with the story was the perspective and mode of narration. I'd never realised how much I cherished chapters until I read Sorrow of War. It's intentionally chaotic, jumping from time to time and place to place with no rhyme or reason. Sometimes it would circle back around and retell events with little in the way new information or insight the second time around. And then the kicker came in the final pages when it was revealed that the manuscript had been taken by an intermediary to a publisher who, surprise, surprise, realised he met Kien in the war. The lack of order wasn't intentional after all - the pages had been disrupted and no one could sort out the correct order again. (To be fair, there were a couple of awkward hints at this earlier on, so it wasn't a shocking plot twist.)
It's all a little too reminiscent of Ian McEwan's wanky manipulation of narrator in Atonement (the bit at the end where he reveals that the last half of the book is a lie, because he's an author and he can do that). I was actually on board with the concept of the shifting, twisting narration - it seemed to me like the book's most interesting comment on The Sorrow - that it was ceaseless, unpredictable and shifting...something that affected the rest of someone's life. But no, it was just because the pages fell apart...

I'm willing to chalk some of my qualms up to the fact that it's a translation (the plot scattering aside!). At times, the dialogue felt wooden and overly formal, and the descriptions sometimes didn't sit right - all likely lost in translation. I understand why this novel is IMPORTANT, and I've certainly been given pause to think further about a time and event which I've frequently taught in History classes, but I didn't enjoy the journey. (less)

A personal account of how the American war affected the author (a Vietnamese living in post-war Hanoi). Sad and depressing â€“ the author is trying to come to terms with his life, his choices, his regrets.
There is a lot of lament, woe, and self-pityâ€¦ When you are in such pain, perhaps all that gives you solace is the bedding of a woman. This distorted perception of life runs in every male character Young ladies be prepared.

It is hard to follow the story because the author jumps around to periods of his life timeline with no seeming order. This is the cultural Sapir-Whorfing of storytelling. His narration of events often confused me and I found myself in a new style of reading whereupon I often had to reimagine the previous events he described to fit new, ongoing details.

But there are moments of beauty in his writing too and to hear a Vietnamese narration of the war is important for Americans.

When I heard Tim Oâ€™Brien speak in college I was surprised that he made up some of the stories, these are after all describing war. He explained how it was necessary to write fiction in war novels because the real brutality of war isn't given its full accord when you write with historical accuracy â€“

But here, the author appears to have made up a number of details â€“ not for any symbolic effect that I can ascertain â€“ just bad storytelling. Is he trying to keep our interest by limiting the number of characters? For example, the 3rd time he saves a woman from being attacked â€“ and itâ€™s his long-lost love Phuong! its clearly unbelievable. Is this some kind of dream-like state where his mind is tortured because he is away from her, or am I reaching for straws trying to justify these storylines.

There are some poignant quips about war, even if some of them are cliche - cliches have a way of being true. Bao describes war behavior as the â€œbrutality that warps soul and personality. The thirst for killing, the cruelty, the animal psychology, the evil desperation.â€ and â€œHeroes in war are inconsistent and contradictory, â€

There were a lot more, but due to my poor reading skills I didn't have a pen handy so now I cannot seem to find those passages. Reminds me of the Mitch Hedburg story about how he has to convince himself his jokes aren't funny so he wouldn't have to get out of bed and get a pen to write them down.

Overall, I was disappointed, despite expectations that this wouldn't be written by Ernest Hemingway, the author's narrative style remains unclear and the message of wars misery is a path well trod on at this point. (less)
Sadly, but Nope...

This book really deserves five stars, let me tell you my journey with it... (There may be some little spoilers, sorry, it's hard to write a review without them)

At first, in about the first 50 pages, I mean, the plot seemed all over the place to me and that wasn't pleasant. The author leaped from one battlefield to another, to one postwar experience to a prewar one, which made the plotline very hard to follow. But as the story progressed, and I got more insides about the protagonist, Kien, I found Ninh's style's purpose. Since the war is so chaotic itself, the structure couldn't be clear. He wanted to express those moments, when you are walking in the streets after a war and you are having flashbacks as clear as if they were happening right now. Also, Kien is a writer, thus he is forced to relive those moments on and on in order to give them to the paper.

So this was clear, but why did I like it so much? Well, the first allusion was Gatsby. In The Sorrow of War, Bao Ninh writes, that Kien wanted to follow that "shining light from the horizons of the past" (217). Come on, this is exactly what Gatsby had! The green light that Nick described. And Gatsby had also fought in a war. Maybe that's why both of them were chasing this light... Because during war you need hope, because, as Ninh says, to be "young, very pure and very sincere" (233). That's why Gatsby was chasing this dream. Because as long as he had the vision of the light, nothing could stop him. That's when Gatsby was so great... He believed his war had a purpose. And his life had a purpose as well. It's all a matter of believing.

And this is when my love towards Naruto comes in. For those who don't know, Naruto is a Japanese Anime by Masashi Kishimoto. And those "human bonds" (233) that Ninh talks about are so deeply explored in there. Naruto showed me that who you are is determined by your bonds. Even if there is war, there is a way to be human and pure, it is by having those strong bonds and believing in the purpose of what you are doing.

An amazing beat, if you want to see my observations while reading the book, you may look at my annotations. (less)

After ten years of fighting as a North Vietnamese soldier, protagonist Kien is writingâ€”as is the author, Bao Ninhâ€”to exorcise the war and to comprehend the incomprehensible: life; death. The Sorrow of War is a meditation, a map of memory superimposed over a map of Vietnam.

Kien describes himself as having taken a U-turn after the war. What he sees before him is not the future, but â€œspreading before him are the past forty yearsâ€ compelling him â€œto march forever along the road of the past.â€

â€œWho else but you can experience your life?â€ These words were spoken to Kien on the eve of war as an encouragement to survive, but they echo throughout the book, because, indeed, no one else can know what we carry around with us. No one can know our past, know what we know, our ghosts, our regrets, the spooling memoriesâ€”unless we write them down, record them somehow.

â€œIt was by night that the old, true stories began to flow back, bringing their own urgency to him. He needed to trap them as they emerged, to get the details down. Parts of stories he thought heâ€™d forgotten floated through his mind, like disconnected mathematical equations, and heâ€™d grab them and pin them down on paper forever.â€

But the writing wonâ€™t bend to Kienâ€™s will. Stories come to him in no particular order, memory and war having their own logic or none at all; time is not a factor, sequence is inconsequential. When Kien disappears at the end of the book, the narrator tries to reassemble the random pages, saying, â€œAny page seemed like the first, any page could have been the last.â€

This suddenly appearing narrator could be Kien himself, transformed, redeemed by the writing, by the exorcising of the past. Or he could be Bao Ninh, the author. But any book-within-a-book quality is only incidental, and whatever is murky in this book is rightly so.

The Sorrow of War: politics doesnâ€™t enter into it.

I really wanted to love this book as I needed something from the NVA perspective for my Vietnam Era class.
Positives:
There were parts in which I will have my class read to show them that the story of the NVA could be of any soldier-in the end the human side of war makes us all the same, no matter which side we are on.
It did show the struggle of the NVA-the length of their war, the suffering, the way life was for them upon their return.
The story of this returning soldier and his struggles with PTSD and adjusting back into civilian life could be the story of a soldier from either side.
Negatives:
There were no breaks in the chapters. The story rambled and went back and forth and then returned to earlier events-it was confusing if you didn't sit and read the story all at once. Putting it down and returning to it over time didn't work.
I didn't appreciate the love story with Phoung until the end when he explains what happened on the train that changed her. Up until then her character was not making sense/a connection to me nor was the character of the mute girl.
In the end they portrayed-the abuse of women during war, the lose of love during war, being changed by war, the need to have someone listen to our war stories but not to respond or critize them.
The concluding part about the storyteller trying to put the author's pages together illustrated why the story was written in such a choppy way-but I still didn't like the writing technique.
I can see why the book was banded in Vietnam and this will help foster discussion in my course about how governments want war to be portrayed versus the reality of it.
Love the human emotion, the raw, realitic account of war-hated the style in which it was written. (less)

I am so torn with this one and till now cannot decide on my general emotion and opinion towards it. I genuinely wanted to love this one; I mean yes, I did like it, but I did not love it. As my first delve into War novels, I expected this book to be emotionally shattering and gut wrenching to say the least, but I was met with slight disappointment.

In defense of the author, it is in itself very difficult to describe your own emotions and horror of War, but even more so to portray them in such a way as to actually succeed in attaining empathy from the readers. This is hardly an excuse though, as I have been driven by other authors to tears from their description of horrific incidents or scenes in a more than sublime manner.

Another issue I had with the reading of this book was in its disorienting and non-linear style. In the closing of the book the fictional narrator, who himself had obtained this fictional manuscript from the fictional protagonist, gives explanation to this style of writing as being due to the "author" of the manuscript writing this not with the intention to publish, but merely because of a necessity to jot down his thoughts as a form of self-therapy. Although it was difficult for me to wrap my head around the flashbacks within the flashbacks and the continuous jumping back and forth in time, I nevertheless do understand how this style can be interpreted to be artistic, and as such won't critic it too harshly in this factor.

Honestly, if not for the beautiful yet grizzly plot, the wonderful yet often interrupted flow of this novel and simply the horrific yet brave and telling stories contained within this book, I would have rated it much lower than I have here. All in all, it was a great read. (less)

How many stories have we seen about the Vietnam war? How many feature the North Vietnamese? This is the first I've seen.

It's fiction but I suspect a great deal is based on the author's experience. He was with the 27th Glorious Youth Brigade, which numbered 500 at the start. He was one of ten who survived.

The protagonist is Kien, a young man who joins the army at the beginning of the war and who survives attack after attack. He sees death almost daily while fighting, and returns home with memories of those who did not make it. In a disjointed way, the way memories take us, the book jolts from one incident to another and back to the present.

Kien falls in love as a teenager and cannot forget Phuong through all the long years, ten long years, and he finds her when he returns. But she is changed just as he is. Ultimately Kien spends most of his time in his little room, writing. Did Bao Ninh do the same? Is that how this novel got written?

The book does not speak from a political position. It is not about North Vietnam so much as it is about war itself, and particularly about such a long, bloody war. It is written simply, with restrained emotion, and is powerful because of that. (less)

When I go to a new country I like to read a novel based in or written in that country. When I went to Vietnam I didn't want to read a Vietnam War book. However I ended up doing so and was not disappointed as this is a brilliant, though harrowing, novel.

Though I shouldn't call it the "Vietnam" war, as it was not confined purely to that country's borders, it was the American War as it is known in that part of the world (a name which could be given to many wars all over the world in the latter half of the 20th and these first two decades of the 21st centuries), so I will call it such.

It is not an orderly. tidy book, it is a mess of flashbacks, jumps forward, tangents and trains of thought. It is shell-shock, it is lying in the back of an army truck bumping through a jungle, it is dying of malaria in a field hospital, it is riding on a train whilst bombs fall all around, it is sleeping next to rotting corpses, it is witnessing the atrocities that man commits against its fellow man, it is the indiscriminate killing of those who have no idea what the ideology in whose name they die even means, it is loss of loved ones, loss of home, loss of self, it is drinking to forget, it is suicidal, it is masochistic, it is sadistic, it is pitiful, it is pitiless, it is a mass of contradictions, rambling thoughts and sober observations. It is a book that many more people should read. (less)

You cannot read this book in parts. It will feel like a jumble of pointlessness. I only truly got into the book after the first 100 pages and ever after that it wasn't like I couldn't put it down or anything.

This probably has to do most with the point of view. To me, it felt like there was no plot. I couldn't really empathize with the narrator and although I felt sad, it was an uncomfortable sort of sad. Like I was going to throw up any second.

Phase 3: Depression

The climax of this book is that one point when the depression level reaches an all-time high. It's at this point when you realize that there is not going to be a happy ending (in case you haven't already caught on by the title 'Sorrow of War').

Phase 4: Reading it again

When I went back, from the beginning, to read the book again in order to prepare for the test, I actually enjoyed the book. The pieces fit together, and it all made sense. That is, I didn't feel utterly confused and out of place during the first 100 pages, trudging through each paragraph grudgingly. (less)

Bao Ninh struck me as one of the sharpest interviewees in the powerful documentary â€œVietnamâ€ by ken burns, with his sorrowful and smart eyes, his soft voice and a constant cigarette smoke hovering in the background. Mainly because of his deep insights. Naturally, I wanted to read his work further and I was curious to read how the Vietnam war is felt and told through Vietnamese eyes.

While Iâ€™m not sure where he draws the line between his own horrible experience and artistic decisions, it obvious that most of his traumatizing experience as a soldier of the North Vietnam forces, had deeply scarred his life and soul.

Itâ€™s an agonizing story written simply and hauntingly, and a very short read that scatters different events and anecdotes, just like the running thoughts of a man remembering flashes from his war. The ending of the book, taking an artistic twist, is beautiful, sad, and very Tarkovskyian.

An amazing book, especially for people interested in the history of the US war with Vietnam. This is a personal first-person account told from the point-of-view of a Vietnamese foot soldier (the author draws upon his experience as a Vietnamese foot soldier). It is not propaganda, nor is it US-bashing. It is a riveting fictional account of the peculiar specificities of that particular tradgedy of war. It is readable, if "gut-wrenching". It offers another view of that war, which Americans often only view from their specific point-of-view. The US lost almost 55,000 citizens in that war; Vietnam lost almost 3 million. One can say "well, the north vietnamese chose to fight that war and to send that many people to die in war"; the author does say this and even questions the logic and morality of the North Vietnamese leadership for doing so. This is another reason why this book is so important to read [especially in a time when a man who spent 6 years as a "high-value" American POW in the "Hanoi Hilton" is running as the Republican nominee for US president (this candidate has indicated that he still thinks that the wrong side won the war)]. This book is structured around a protagonist Kien and his attempt - through writing a novel after the war - to rid himself of his memories of the war and of his relationship with Phuong, his childhood sweetheart, and its gradual disintegration during and after the war.

Probably the overwhelming response of American readers to this book is that it humanizes the Vietnamese during the Vietnam War: and thank god. The most common explanation for North Vietnam's victory is that the North Vietnamese were determined to end centuries of colonization and willing to fight until they happened - in other words, that the war of attrition was a strategy that failed to understand that the North Vietnamese couldn't be worn down. So it's moving and emotional to read an account of a person disintegrating, who sees no point to much of the suffering he's surrounded by.

For me, reading about Kien and Phuong's relationship also gave Hanoi an interesting and young-feeling dimension, picturing it not just as an outsider for once but through the eyes of young kids on their bicycles riding past big West Lake young at sunset and in love. (less)

As you learn from the jacket, the author of this book was among the 10 survivors of the brigade of 500 soldiers he joined in 1969. So you know right away that this is not going to be an easy book to read, and it's not. It's difficult to read because the most horrible death and destruction stalks every page. But it's also literally hard to read, because it pretty much breaks all the rules of story-telling. There are no chapters, and little structure. It reads pretty much like a dream (a nightmare that is). You know the ending before you know all of its significance. It's a bit like a puzzle, and part of what keeps you reading is a desire for all the pieces to drop into place.

It was a terrible war, and the only hope in this book are the few instances when things could have been worse. To be honest, the only war stories I've read are a series of midieval warfare books that take place in Europe in the 1300's. But, given that inexperience, what seems to set this book apart from others for me is that the protagonist was our enemy, yet despite what we've been told, seems exactly like us. (less)

Comparable in some ways to All Quiet on the Western Front, rather than build up a plot, this book layers the reader's understanding of the soldier, Kien, before, during and after the Vietnam war, along with his teenage sweetheart Phuong. There are glimpses of the horror of war, the tormented mind afterwards of a veteran, told through snatches of stark, honest prose, where the enemy is not so much fighters on the other side of the battle, but war itself, and its swathe of destruction on a generation's mind and heart. Although there are occasional graphic war scenes, more raw is the emotional power seen through the lens of time when "The Jungle of Screaming Souls" is revisited through present and past images painted on a canvas that pulses in the reader's heart.
There are occasional sections where the descriptive narrative seems strained, or the images of a veteran's struggle seem more hollow than the rest of the book, but by and large this leaves the reader with a soaring loathing of those who force war onto the lives of the young, regardless of political ideology. Since it's written by a North Vietnamese Army veteran, this book is a chance to glimpse the other side of the Vietnam War and see our old enemies in a more human light--not simply as cannon fodder for 80's action movies. This is a passionate, disturbing book written in the tone of somebody who is utterly shell-shocked, thereby giving the narrative an almost dream-like quality which makes the atrocities of the story seem rather otherworldly and unreal. My one problem with the novel, though, is its structure. There is little overall story arc and events are recorded completely out of sequence, so it's easy to lose track of the novel's chronology. But that's definitely the way the author wanted it to be presented: as though his thoughts had been vomited onto the page rather than written down carefully. I'd recommend reading When Heaven and Earth Changed Places instead, but The Sorrow of War is nonetheless a haunting account of a dark time in world history. (less)

This novel of the Vietnam War is interesting for its graphic depictions of the war as it really was for the North Vietnamese soldiers, a civil war between North and South with the Americans an anonymous mass threatening from a distance but rarely the focus. Ninh's writing leaps around in time without any attempt to coherently link events for the reader which gives a fantastic insight into the mind of a soldier destroyed by war, but also makes this a difficult book to understand. Perhaps that is its point. The love story between Kien and Phuong, both little more than children at the war's outbreak, is movingly tender when set against so much violence and their loss of innocence could just as well apply to the whole country that was ripped apart by over a decade of conflict. The amount of are emotion pushed into this novel is heart-breaking. I should give this 4 stars, because it is a horribly good book. But it was so hard to enjoy reading it, and I came out of it full of grief, not wanting to dwell. Am I glad I read it? Yes. Will I ever read it again? No.

Absolutely extraordinary book, which shocked, saddened and devastated me. The storytelling was immediately immersive and involved a nostalgic yet tragic romance, thrilling and terrifying war reports, and brutally honest reflections from one man heavily involved in the violent upheaval of his country.

Extremely autobiographical, but actually historical fiction, Bao Ninh tells the story of Kien. Kien was a soldier in the American War in Vietnam, fighting for Communist North Vietnam - but this book was banned by the Communist party because of its critical and personal perspective. When we first meet him, it is towards the end of the war and he is in the Jungle of Screaming Souls, collecting and identifying bodies. The mood is melancholy and ethereal - he cannot sleep because he is haunted by memories and ghosts of dead comrades and current corpses he sleeps above in his truck as he gathers the dead.

Although our author has difficulty distinguishing reality, his recollections are vivid and violent. Check out this passage from page 3: "The diamondâ€“shaped glass clearing was piled high with bodies killed by helicopter gunships. Broken bodies, bodies blown apart, bodies vaporized. No jungle grew again in this clearing. No grass. No plants. â€œBetter to die than surrender my brothers? Better to die?â€ the battalion commander yelled insanely; waving his pistol in front of Kien he blew his own brains out through his ear. Kien screamed soundlessly in his throat at the sight, as the Americans attacked with submachine guns, sending bullets buzzing like deadly bees around him. Then Kien lowered his machine gun, grasped his side and fell, rolling slowly down the bank of a shallow stream, hot blood trailing down the slope after him (Ninh, 5)." That's page THREE guys. You are immediately thrust into the awful action of an atrocious war, and though the horror continues, it really actually deepens as we discover more about our author and his experiences.

The story doesn't have chapters and it switches from first to third person perspective frequently - its actually the story of him writing a story of his memoirs from the war, and we learn more about his personal past (childhood, relationship with parents, early romance, etc) through his reflections. He feels haunted by his history and has survivor's guilt, and realizes midway through the book that he must write a book to process, recover and redeem himself. Characters dead reappear as he fleshes out their role, and his past lover from childhood reappears in the present time. The story circles and doubles back on itself often, representing the role of memory in an individual, and also the PTSD of a solider whose existence and country has been totally redefined by war.

But this isn't just about soldiers - in this book, and in this war historically, we are forced to focus on the ways that civilian lives have been wrecked and ruined and redefined by the tragedy of war. He doesn't delve into details - he is up-front and forward with the full exposure which war brings to simple people, and doesn't need to dress it up with disclaimers or details. Surviving soldiers live paralyzed and permanently scarred lives, mothers are devastated by losing multiple children or entire households...everyone is affected to an awful extent...

There are multiple subplots, notably with his father and with his childhood sweetheart, which delve more deeply into the psychological catastrophes which each person endures due to the war, and we recognize over and over that the sorrow of war has nothing to do with wins and losses, statistics, timelines, or death tolls; but rather, the ruin which indiscriminately redefines each individual.

This book is beautifully written and effectively agonizing. As a pacifist, it persuaded me even more in my sentiments. As someone who lived in Vietnam two years, it broke my heart but built up my amazement at their recovery and forgiveness of foreign oppressors. As a book lover, I was swept away by the tragic tone, the clever circular delivery of the narrative and the layers of meaning. As someone who empathized with the author, it made me want to be more courageous in love as I read about the boldness of destruction and The Sorrow of War.

War is hell. And here is why.

There is no shortage of media content made about the Vietnam War. You find it in music, books, and video games. You find it in pop culture. However, you almost exclusively find it described from a perspective of an American. And like most of the war content anywhere, it is unnaturally romanticized. War is noble. War is awesome. War is a fight for freedom. War has clear winners and obvious losers. The archetype of a war hero is a virtuous and honorable warrior that easily tells right from wrong, fights for justice, and in the end, returns to the happy, healthy family that eagerly awaits for him, safe and sound.

Well, no. It is not like that. At all.

This book tells a story from a viewpoint of a Northern Vietnamese soldier, a youngling named Kieu. He leaves his family, his education and his high-school love to go fight in a bloody, merciless conflict against his rebellious compatriots and foreign invaders.

Like the war itself, this book is chaotic. Timeline is non-existent. The stories inside are jaw-dropping in the most horrendous way. The veneer of civilization is scraped away so many times and the horrifying nature of the human animal is shown beneath, explicitly showing all the acts of brutality people are ready to commit once the fog of war engulfs the nation. Rape and slaughter, mayhem and murder, that is the reality of this conflict that Bao Ninh vividly portrays here.

Hand-in-hand with macabre depictions of war times, there are other excerpts of pre-war events that show what life looked like before the carnage started. First loves, happy families, plans of the future. It is all here, but it doesn't serve the purpose of giving this book merry overtones or an idea of a happy ending. There are here to turn the volume up on the melancholic tune and to crystalize the central theme of this book: the sorrow of war. Everything that war, any war, takes away.

In one of his novels, famous American writer Kurt Vonnegut compared writing anti-war books to writing anti-glacier books because â€there would always be wars, that they were as easy to stop as glaciersâ€œ. This book dismisses that notion and through vivid descriptions and reminiscence subtly embraces one of the finest anti-war rhetoric I have seen. And even if it fails in that intention, it still serves as a stark reminder that once the war starts, no soldier on the field is a winner.

I try my best to write about books in the language in which I read them, and I read The Sorrow of War in my native tongue. But I know well-intentioned Americans and foreigners often seek this book out to compensate for the omnipresent American perspective on the Second Indochina War, and none of the GR reviews I scoured through said anything about this matter (which I myself also only learned of just this year!), so, on the off-chance this is useful to a potential readerâ€¦

If you ever plan to read The Sorrow of War in Englishâ€”the version in which it is most read, way more than the original, which was banned until 2006 in Vietnamâ€”you should know that what is called a â€œtranslationâ€ by Frank Palmos is more of a re-writing. Phan Thanh Hao produced a raw translation of Bao Ninhâ€™s book. Then, an Australian journalist named Frank Palmos wrote an English version based on the raw translation. For what itâ€™s worth, Bao Ninh agreed with this arrangement and met with both guys several times. Most translations are based on what Palmos wrote, except for a version in French, Japanese, and Chinese, or so Wikipedia tells me. Iâ€™m sure some of my friends who study comparative literature & translation theory can present actual arguments for whether this is a Good or a Bad thing, but personally, Iâ€™m inclined to feel annoyed about all of this.

Now that I cautioned youâ€¦ Iâ€™m not sure how much is lost or invented in translation, but what I read in Vietnamese, written by Bao Ninh, is a great novel, not a piece of propaganda or a textbook on the Vietnam War. Literature should be something else, something more than politics or even historyâ€”and this was it.
