This novel was an assigned reading for my HIS 112 class during the period in which we covered the Vietnam War. Báº£o Ninh writes about Kien, a North Vietnamese soldier, who details his life within the scope of war in a manuscript; from prewar, during war, and postwar.

One of the most noticeable features of the book is that it is not written in chronological order and also does not have any chapters or other obvious stopping points besides line breaks. Although confusing and hard to follow at first (I should preface that I have not had any experience with this writing style before), the intentions behind this stylistic choice are explained within the novel, both by Kien and an unnamed character that appears towards the end. This style is meant to encapsulate the inner monologue and glimpses of the past that appear to Kien.

Kien is not the perfect protagonist either; his innocence and timidness slowly fade as rage and sorrow take over his mind over the course of the war, influencing his actions and words. By the end, he is a broken man and slips into alcoholism to cope with his PTSD.

The novel covers several themes including sacrifice, trauma, loss, grief, love, comradeship and paints them very vividly as we journey with Kien across his "river of life." As the title implies, this book is very sorrowful and heavy; it can weigh the soul down. Definitely take your time with it, step back, and reflect as Kien does.

I believe this piece would also be an interesting reread as it is not in chronological order as previously mentioned. Some of the characters and locations were briefly introduced towards the beginning of the novel with not much context surrounding them only to be delved deeper into within the story.

Overall, this novel was an important piece to read and immerse myself in. I'm thankful my Professor assigned this to us and included different works and perspectives from citizens of the countries we studied. (less)

The Aesthetics of Remembering the Dead and the Loving
by Van A. Huebner

(Tim Oâ€™Brienâ€™s The Things They Carried
and
Bao Ninhâ€™s The Sorrow of War)

Timothy Oâ€™Brien and Bao Ninh provide us with a good opportunity to demonstrate what I propose to investigate more thoroughly at some other time. But for the purposes of the moment let me digress a little and begin by referring to M. Merleau-Pontyâ€™s, Phenomenology of Perception. M-P mentions the difficulty of knowing more than one language and states that one â€œnever does belong to two worlds at once [while he does acknowledge] selves conversing in the void [...when] madness is very near.â€

â€œIt is impossible to superimpose on man a lower layer of behavior which one chooses to call â€˜natural,â€™ followed by a manufactured cultural or spiritual world. Everything is both manufactured and natural in man, as it were, in the sense that there is not a word, not a form of behavior which does not owe something to purely biological beingâ€•and which at the same time does not elude the simplicity of animal life, and cause forms of vital behavior to deviate from their pre-ordained direction, through a sort of leakage and through a genius for ambiguity which might serve to define man [....] It is impossible to draw up an inventory of this irrational power which creates meanings and conveys them.â€
[M. Merleau-Ponty, Phenomenology of Perception]

While I would agree to the impossibility of such an inventory of powers, I would argue that this â€œpower of giving shape to stimuli and situations[...]â€ and this leakage are precisely what the two authors in question have done and exemplifyâ€•an organic, symbolic re-combination and differentiation of fact. Firstly, the authors resided as it were in two worlds at once, their former civilized world of kindness and calm, yet also in a world of an animalistic indiscretion and violence, the inhumanity of cruelty, brutality. They have seen the real result of war, the spillage of blood, they know intimately the â€œleakage,â€ thus the feeling of that â€œvital force [which] flowed from [Kien].â€ And yet as well the being caught up in the flowâ€•such as when, in The Things They Carried, "life seemed to be collapsing toward slaughter [....] All around me the options seemed to be narrowing, as if I were hurtling down a huge black funnel, the whole world squeezing in tight." [Tim Oâ€™Brien] These authors then, through their main characters, show this dual belonging that can exist for creatures forced to endure the extraordinary, the upside down and foul doctrine of war: killing is acceptable and requiredâ€•and that they must retain the previous moral stability as well so as to revert to it when the killing is finished.

This residing in two worlds at once exists as well for any fiction writer in a sense. They must maintain a â€˜hold on reality,â€™ as they say, while they imagine another. In order to fashion this other world they must have more than just lingual skill, but also the psychic power to pass between both worlds at a given moment such as required to sustain them both. A power which at times is as heavy as the burden their protagonists carry: â€œIf only he could shed all other needs of everyday living and concentrate all his energies into writing[...]â€ about the carrying of this burdenâ€•this retelling of this horrible condition that all soldiers endureâ€•for it may indeed have been a â€œsacred dutyâ€ [Bao Ninh] for the writer to endure and survive such â€œSorrow...â€

Both Oâ€™Brien and Bao have also attempted to describe this very difficult task of remaining sane while being torn apart between these two moral worlds that they experienced, by allowing their protagonist to live out the ambiguity of it. The landscape then becomes the symbolic inversion of this: â€œRivers of fire,â€ â€œpeace [as] a tree that thrives only on the blood and bonesâ€â€• such that Kien can see the â€œbeautiful landscape of calm and peace [as] an appalling paradox;â€ or after war it is the â€œsoft surfacesâ€ that bring back the memory of it. There is as well the symbolic conjugation between the two worlds: such as when O'Brien's Kiowa, first flesh, then all at once swallowed up by the earth, becomes one with the war. The author by seeing it thus comes back more complete, but inevitably much heavier for these ghosts that cling to him. While the soldier must sustain an extraordinary self-composure during this time of war, this extraordinary time; his psychic makeup all along, his ordinary upbringing, is telling him that his behavior is akin to the hangmanâ€™s or the serial killerâ€™s in his otherwise ordinary times to which he must return.
The writer as well must slip through the psychic membrane of the reader without rupturing this delicate attentive bubble. And it must be done by maintaining an extraordinary and supple voice overall in order to implant what might even in the end be the inability-to-circumscribe reality as it was a priori the conceiving of it. This seed of truth is something other than an inventory of facts; and once an author dissects it, the totality of facts become a new truth. This the artist must relate to a readerâ€™s satisfaction without too much sacrifice or leakage. Otherwise the objectification becomes as Mishimaâ€™s apple or Wittgensteinâ€™s ladder, and we must then confess that weâ€™ve failed to convey anything at all but the de-constructive process.
In a sense we could say these are novels of the ultimate rite of passage. Passage in the ordinary sense would have us recalling the freshets of childhood and the wild adolescence that might once have caused us to grimace, but now perhaps elicit only a smirk, or a chuckle. But crushes and pining become uncommon in true literature. And these crossings over take us neither to Canada; nor merely deeper into a dark continent. These are not ordinary rivers and jungle paths. And they are neither an anthropologistâ€™s quaint â€˜soul catchingâ€™ of, nor â€˜vision questâ€™ for, representative spirits. These are the kindred morphs of modernism sheared, a consecration of livingâ€™s defilement; as the artists fairly say â€œto the Worm: Thou art my mother and my sister,â€ [William Blake] both Timothy Oâ€™Brien and Bao Ninh find redemption in the aesthetics of remembering the dead and the loving. This is the single most beautiful, touching, nightmarish, horrifying book I have ever read.

The true nightmare of war, as described by Ninh, isn't merely the barbarism of violence itself, but the way every moment of one's life is irrevocably lashed to it. War is not a neat chapter of one's life, like a chapter of a book with a beginning and an end, instead the tendrils of its memory coil around every moment of one's life. Every passing moment ignites a memory of a fellow soldier, brain hollowed out by enemy rounds or drowned to death in a swamp or worse. There is no aspect of your life that remains untouched, except perhaps the memories of life before war, pure in their innocence. But in those memories lies madness too, because those youthful moments are not preserved in amber, waiting for your return. They, too, have been destroyed.

The prose here is gutting, filled with a sort of matter-of-fact sorrow that just sort of hurts to read. A loose, rambling structure, in which one memory naturally follows another, only further emphasizes the unyielding corruption of war. No matter where you stand, what you do, who you see, what you choose to remember and what you hope to forget, your mind will inevitably slink past it back into thoughts of ghosts.

It's just, it's just really good. It's good in a way that I now feel absolutely terrible. (less)

The Long Silence of Bao Ninh
By Rohit Inani.

In the fall of 2018, Rohit Inani, a freelance journalist based in New Delhi, contacted CounterPunch contributor Marc Levy after reading his 1998 interview with Bao Ninh. Rohit, who admires Ninhâ€™s work, asked to be put in touch with Ninh. Later, the monsoon rains wash the city, igniting the â€œspirit of Hanoi,â€ which, according to Kienâ€”the protagonist of The Sorrow of War, Ninhâ€™s daring and wildly popular 1990 novel based on his experiences in the Vietnam warâ€”is â€œstrongest by night, even stronger in the rain. Like now, when the whole town seems deserted, wet, lonely, cold, and deeply sad.â€

We met at a cafe in downtown Hanoi, favoured by journalists, artists, and middle-ranking officials of the Communist Party of Vietnam, which has ruled the country since the end of the war in 1975. Ninh rarely engages with the press or gives interviews, preferring a quiet and simple life in Hanoi, which he seldom leaves. Outside, on the street, a light wind blew and the sun shone on the window pane, occasionally capturing Ninhâ€™s attention. He lit a cigarette. â€œI appreciate your efforts and your interest in me, but there is not much to say,â€ he said to me through his interpreter Nguyen Phoung Loan. â€œIâ€™m a writer. I can write but Iâ€™m not very good at talking about myself.â€

Ninh is handsome, with a thatch of wavy, ash-grey hair and deep, glum eyes. â€œShall we begin?â€ he said. â€œDonâ€™t have much time. I might have to undergo a surgery tomorrow.â€ In the first week of May, Ninh was diagnosed with a cancerous tumor, the consequence of years of dependence on alcohol and tobacco, a habit he acquired after he returned home from the war, to a troubled post-war life, writing and drinking from night till dawn in his home, at the time a squalid pad in Central Hanoi.

Ninh, who will turn sixty-six this October, is Vietnamâ€™s most celebrated writer, best-known for The Sorrow of War, which was immediately deemed a classic of war narrative when published in English in 1994, earning comparisons with Erich Maria Remarqueâ€™s famous All Quiet on The Western Front, a novel about the experiences of German soldiers during the First World War. Based on Ninhâ€™s time as a North Vietnamese soldier, who served with the Glorious 27th Youth brigadeâ€”of the five hundred who went to war in 1969, Ninh was one of the ten who survived; of these, six later committed suicideâ€”the novel recounts the experiences of its anti-hero, Kien, a middle-aged war veteran chronicling his war memories while collecting the bodies of his fallen comrades in the jungles of Central Vietnam. In 1994, Ninh became the first Vietnamese writer to win an overseas literary prize when The Sorrow of War bagged The Independent Foreign Fiction Prize, trumping Italo Calvinoâ€™s The Road to San Giovanni, among others. At the awards ceremony in Hay-on-Wye, Robert Winder, then the literary editor of The Independent, called the novel â€œhistoric,â€ and remarked, while announcing the award: â€œUsually, history is the story told by the winners; Bao Ninhâ€™s book reminds us that, in war, everybody loses.â€

At the end of the Second World War, Vietnam, which had been a French colony, fought the French for independence, led by Ho Chi Minh and his communist front Viet Minh. In 1954, after the Viet Minh forces defeated France, the war was settled by the signing of the Geneva Accords, which also temporarily divided Vietnam along a latitude commonly referred to as the seventeenth parallel. Determined to unify Vietnam and drive out the â€œAmerican imperialists,â€ Ho Chi Minhâ€”meaning the â€œbringer of lightâ€â€”intensified his attacks on the South, which was at the time supported by the United States and led by the anti-communist leader Ngo Dinh Diem. This began the twenty-year conflict in 1955 between the communist-ruled north and the south. The Cold War was also ongoing at the time, and the Vietnamese conflict ricocheted inside the hallways of Pentagon. In 1965, fearing a communist victory in Vietnam, the United States dispatched the first combat troops to the country. The ensuing war raged for a decade and exacted a huge human toll, especially on the Vietnamese side. On 30 April 1975, at noon, Saigon fell. As news of victory filtered to the north, people hit the streets, waving flags and cheering, â€œVietnam, Ho Chi Minh! Vietnam, Ho Chi Minh!â€

As the sounds of victory dimmed, Vietnam, finally reunited after decades of war, came to terms with the price it had paid to realize a long-cherished dream. The country had been devastated, its cities and towns ruined by unabated aerial bombings. Five million hectares of forests and vegetation were destroyed by high-grade explosives and chemicals, including an estimated forty-three million litres of Agent Orange. Over three million Vietnamese people had been killed. And with plummeting Soviet aid at a time of international isolation, the nationâ€™s socialist economic model had completely collapsed. In 1986, after almost a decade of high inflation and widespread poverty, the Communist Party took measures to liberalise the economy, a move that became known as the Doi Moi reforms, and led Vietnam, two decades later, to become one of the worldâ€™s fastest-growing economies. In 2008, The Economist called it â€œAsiaâ€™s other miracleâ€ after China.

The current generation of Vietnamese adults is too young to remember the war. On the margins of this shift stands Ninh, author of the countryâ€™s most cherished war novel, who not only spoke to the generation that fought the war, but humanised its victims, and in doing so, broke away from Vietnamese officialdom, which remained a cocktail of patriotism, glory, and propaganda. At the height of the war, radio broadcasts in Hanoi and most of north Vietnam described the war as â€œjust,â€ asked for the â€œdevotionâ€ of the North Vietnamese Army troops toward the Communist Party, and routinely referred to the south as a â€œpuppetâ€ administration of the United States. â€œIt was crucial when it came out and remains crucial today, when many Vietnamese either do not know anything about their wartime past or would choose to forget what they know,â€ Viet Thanh Nguyen, the Pulitzer prize-winning Vietnamese-American writer, told me over email. But while an entire generation is putting its past behind it, attempting to find a new national identity, Ninh is reluctant to move on. In Hanoi, I interviewed several of his friends, writers and veterans, most of whom spoke of his two defining traits, traits that have remained unchanged for years: his silence, his sadness.

One afternoon, over vodka and endless cigarettes in the conference room of the Vietnam Writersâ€™ Association, an official culture association under the Communist Party, some of Ninhâ€™s closest writer friends sat at a long teakwood table and waited for lunch to be served. Mr. Doan, tell us about Bao Ninh,â€ he said, in jest. KIEN, THE NARRATOR OF The Sorrow of War, joins the NVA in 1969 at the age of twenty-one, at a time when a patriotic wave is sweeping Vietnam in response to the enemy invasion. He joins Battalion 27, a unit comprising five hundred mostly young men, and in the dry season of that year, the whole group is almost entirely decimated by napalm fires in the jungle. In 1976, after the end of the war, Kien returns to the Central Highlands as part of the Missing In Action body collecting team and, on board a Russian-built Zil truck, reaches the Jungle of Screaming Souls. At one point, still somewhat hopeful for the future, Kien asks the truck driver, â€œBut isnâ€™t peace better than war?â€ to which he replies:
â€œThis kind of peace? In this kind of peace it seems people have unmasked themselves and revealed their true, horrible selves. So much blood, so many lives were sacrificed for what?â€
â€œDamn it, what are you trying to say?â€™ Kien asked.

â€œIâ€™m not trying to say anything. Iâ€™m simply a soldier like you whoâ€™ll now have to live with broken dreams and with pain. But, my friend, our era is finished. After this hard-won victory fighters like you, Kien, will never be normal again. You wonâ€™t even speak with your normal voice, in the normal way again.â€

Ninh, like Kien, enlisted with the NVA at the age of seventeen after dropping out of high school in 1969. He was among the thousands of young men who answered the call of the Communist Party to fight the Americans and unify Vietnam. Ninh answered the call â€œjust like any other Vietnamese at the time,â€ he told me, cigarette smoke spiraling around his face. â€œYou were eager and excited to do that.â€ When he showed up at the recruiting camp, he was greeted by performers singing songs of glory, drumming up the patriotic spirit of the young fighters. By the time the war ended, the soldiers who survived returned to the North as victors. They were hailed as heroes by the government, but Ninh came back devastated. â€œEach day brought new nightmares; even my parents feared me. I was keen to forget the war, but it refused to release its grip on me,â€ he told a gathering at the Southeast Asian Literature Forum in Taiwan this March.

In the novel, as Kien recalls his fallen comrades, he comes to grip with the horrors of war, and while moving month after month through the â€œmountains and jungles, water-soaked and dullâ€¦ muddy as all hell,â€ ghosts are resurrected as the wandering dead, who come to haunt the living. â€œThe dead step from every corner, every house, every jungle trail, creating a narrative structure that feels like a tide coming in and washing outâ€”relentlessâ€”more like labyrinth upon labyrinth than any solid Aristotelian form,â€ noted the Canadian novelist Madeleine Thien, writing about the novel on the PEN America website.

Ninh rejects narrative conventions in The Sorrow of War, adopting a highly non-linear structure, shifting between past and present in an effort to collapse and immobilize time. Later in the novel, Kien begins to write a book and eventually finds that â€œthe act of writing blurs his neat designs, finally washing them away altogether, or blurs them so the lines become intermixed and sequences lose their order.â€

Viet Thanh Nguyen elaborated on this aspect of the novel over email.

Linear, coherent storytelling in regards to the war and the revolution are the features of government-sanctioned storytelling, in films, novels, and especially historical museums. This kind of storytelling pins all the blame on enemy outsiders and internal traitors, and paints the soldiers, guerrillas, and revolutionaries as optimistic, noble patriots. Bao Ninhâ€™s novel tells a radically different story about how these young patriots were utterly destroyed by the war. That much is coherent. But when one is utterly destroyed, can one be coherent? This is a terrific move by a novelist who understands, implicitly or explicitly, how trauma works.

â€œThe war is like an obsession for him,â€ Pham Xuan Nguyen, a writer and a popular literary critic in Hanoi, told me. â€œWhatever he writes, it will be about the war. Ninh is the kind of person who needs to be thrown into such events like the war â€¦ to become a writer. And this warâ€”if Iâ€™m not exaggeratingâ€”has chosen him to write about it.â€

Pham occasionally paused as we talked, as if trying to find the perfect words to describe the indescribable: the post-war years in Vietnam and his longtime friend, Ninh. â€œFor Vietnamese soldiers, when you returned, there were two things that caused them trauma,â€ he said. â€œFirst was the question of why they were still alive when their comrades had died. In The Sorrow of War, after Kien returns to Hanoi, he looks back at his years, and reminisces.
From now on life may be always dark, full of suffering, with brief moments of happiness. Living somewhere between a dream world and reality, on the knife-edge between the two. Iâ€™ve lived all these lost years. No one to blame for that. Not me, not anyone elseâ€¦Thereâ€™s a new life ahead of me, and a new era for Vietnam. I have to survive. After the defeat of the French army and their subsequent withdrawal from North Vietnam in 1954, his family moved to Hanoi. The Sorrow of War: A Novel of Vietnam (1991) is his story of Kien, a soldier in the NVA from 1965 through the end of the war in 1975. Kien is clearly the authorâ€™s doppelganger, the ghost at Baoâ€™s side as he wrote the novel. Kien is looking back from his vantage in 1990, remembering his comrades, counting his losses, living not for his future but for his memories so that his dead comrades might not permanently disappear.

This novel is both haunting and beautiful in its description of the terrors of war in a harsh terrain with constant bad weather, with very limited resources, and with constant political indoctrinationâ€”as if an army marches on its politics, not its stomach. Like most soldiers whoâ€™ve experienced combat, Kien is trapped in the war long after its end. He writes,

From the horizon of the distant past an immense sad wind, like an endless sorrow, gusts and blows through the villages, through the cities, and through my life.
Kien was a platoon commander, equivalent to a lieutenant, responsible for three squads of patrol scouts, about forty men. He had to know his men both inside and out, to anticipate their actions and reactions, and to bolster their spirits and contain their excesses. So through Kien we learn about the NVA men of war, and we learn the burden that such intimate knowledge carries in war.

The staging area for Kienâ€™s brigade was in â€œThe Jungle of Screaming Souls." (Indications suggest that this was around Ngoc Linh , a four-peaked mountain at the â€œroof of South Vietnamâ€ near Laos and Cambodia. During the pauses some men deserted, like Can who set off to find his mother in Hanoi and was found days later only a two-hour walk from the camp, already a near skeleton enmeshed in vegetation. Kien survived an entire decade of life in combat: moments of extreme violence and terror, stretches of boredom awaiting terror, constant losses of friends and piecemeal disappearance of his soul.

Sledgeâ€™s With the Old Breed: at Peleilu and Okinawa (1981), or Karl Marlantesâ€™ more recent Matterhorn (2009)â€”all very powerful books by Marines. I first read this book as a part of my curriculum in my English class two years ago. As a class, we read this book to further our knowledge about the suffers from the people living in North Vietnam and the horrors of war. This was the first real look that a lot of us have had of this war. In reality, this war was a brutal conflict between the United States and these people. The main reason I enjoyed this novel was how honest it was. It told of stories of rape, murder, and war crimes. It told the real truth of this war, not the doctored version we were taught in school. Many of my peers that read this book disliked this, which speaks volumes of the level of maturity and academic prowess found in this grade level.

I learned much from this novel. I value the way it was taught to us and the things that I learned will stick with me. In my opinion, it is imperative that as young adults we are exposed to these kinds of stories. History is an important part of our journey in education. By taking concepts like war and rape seriously, we can raise more sympathetic, kind, and informed adults. The point of view this story was told in is extremely raw and honest. Bao Ninh makes you feel like you are in the trenches right there with them. The Sorrow of War is an emotional and personal documentary of the events that are a result of the Vietnam War.

I recommend this novel to anyone who can appreciate the concepts that will be discussed and really learn from them. An excellent account of a North Vietnamese soldier's experience in the Vietnam war. The Sorrow of War is presented as fiction, but the author was a surviving veteran, and most of the book reads as being autobiographical (or at least semi so).

The vast majority of writing about the Vietnam War published in the West has been from a US perspective. This book acts as a kind of corrective as, here, the US, along with the South Vietnamese ARVN, is the enemy. The novelâ€™s viewpoint character is a North Vietnamese soldier, Kien, whom we first meet in his post-war duty of collecting for burial the remains of corpses left over from the war. This is in an eerie place the soldiers named the Jungle of Screaming Souls. One corpse is discovered in a colourless plastic bag and the body seems immaculate. Then it discolours, something seems to escape, and it deflates. The platoon takes this apparition as a soul departing. This scene is emblematic as, while the memories of combat are no doubt authentic, so much of what Binh describes here is surreal. Many descriptions of war are.

The novel is disjointed, fragmented, as if reflecting the uncanny nature of such experiences. Ninh tells us the sorrow of war is like the sorrow of love, â€œa kind of nostalgia,â€ a â€œsadness, a missing, a pain which could send one soaring back into the past.â€ The novel is a patchwork of such pain, of things unforgettable, surfacing unbidden from memory. â€œHis fighting life was being revived in flashbacks, or in slowly unfolding scenes as heart-rending as a funeral march.â€ War as an experience is perhaps best encapsulated when Kien remembers trying to dissuade his comrade Can from deserting as it would be shameful. Can replied, â€œâ€˜In all my time as a soldier Iâ€™ve yet to see anything honourable.â€™â€

While combat and its horrors - the blood and entrails carried on the tracks of tanks so that they have to be driven through a river to clean them, Kienâ€™s friend killed when his tank is all-but vapourised by a shell, the dreamlike quality of being on the receiving end of a US air-raid, the self-sacrifice of an inexperienced female guide named Hua who distracted a platoon of US soldiers away from a group of wounded NVA personnel whom she had put in danger of discovery - The Sorrow of War is not merely a story of firefights and military life. The story flits between those and his pre-Army life in Hanoi with Kienâ€™s golden memories of his girlfriend Phuong and of life after the war where it is not only Kien who has been changed utterly but also Phuong, forever scarred by her travails when she accompanied him south to his first posting and her subsequent struggles to subsist in Hanoi.

The end of the war brought to the soldiers no soaring, brilliant happiness such as Kien saw later on film, only memories and nightmares. â€œThose who had died and those who lived on shared a common fate in this war.â€ As to the future, â€œLosses can be made good, damage can be repaired and wounds will heal in time. But the psychological scars of the war will remain forever.â€ The survivors â€œhad lost not only the capacity to live happily with others but also the capacity to be in love.â€

Since Kien later sets out to write about his impressions of the war the novel also contains observations on writing. Binh tells us the author wrote â€œbecause he had to write, not because he had to publish.â€ This is of course the way round the process ought to be.

Despite all its gruesome content and incident, its record of manâ€™s inhumanity to man - and woman - The Sorrow of War is not difficult to read, a testament to both Binh and his translators.

Some books hit and hit hard. "Sorrow" hits hard not only because of the subject matter of the Vietnam War, but how it's written. It's a tremendously beautiful book, full of longing and nostalgic tremors. Ninh writes of a Vietnam that was, and a Vietnam that became. In some ways, "Sorrow" is meditative, a necessary exercise for the author to get rid of his demons. Bao Ninh was one of ten in a batallion of five hundred who survived. "Sorrow" is a testament of that survival.

It is easy to compare it to O'Brien's "The Things They Carried" - some of the stories of the Vietnamese jungle are eerily similar. For example, in "Things", O'Brien mentioned a mysterious symphony playing in the jungle, almost like an orchestra. Ninh mentioned music in the jungle too, haunting and melodious. I wonder if the marines in "Things" were listening to Vietnamese music.

"Sorrow" has no beginning and end. There is no suspense here. Kien, the narrator, described fairly early on how his comrades were going to die, in the battle for Saigon. The deaths of soldiers here, and the victims are never glorified, and always a waste. War gives the dead reprieve, and the survivors ghosts. There are no chapters either, the story (if you want to call it) flows from one paragraph to the next, without structure. And it works so well.

The book is about lost things. Time is divided into before and after the war, and so do the people. The mainstay of the book is Kien's childhood sweetheart, Phuong. She is a truly incredible character and the moments they spend together are absolutely gut-wrenching. As Kien described: "He had only two loves in his entire life. Phuong at seventeen in the pre-war days, and Phuong now, after the war." War and events like these changes people into two - divides them, damages them.

There are lost moments in the book that haunt him, perhaps haunts Ninh - hesitation in the battlefield, sexual tensions with girls, people who he'd never meet again. It is a book about memories. More than that - it is a book about writing. The book is borne from the author out of a necessity to write. As much as he wanted to burn his work at the end, I can understand why the author has that love and hate relationship with his work - the act of writing more important than what's written.

There are brutal moments too, of course. People forget themselves during wartime - they seem to switch to their base nature. Women become victims of violence, men fight each other over squabbles, corpses littered the jungles and backs of trucks, hammocks hanging above while the living sleeps above the dead. But there is much beauty in this brutality too. Kien's batallion found a woman's naked corpse and out of respect, dressed her before putting her with the rest of pile of corpses. It is an act of grace.

When I talk to people about this book, they tell me that it sounds depressing. Sure, it can be. But like any amazing books that blow you out of the water, you are left with a strange feeling of satisfaction. In some way, I'd like to think that Ninh found some reprieve by publishing this incredible book. (less)

I'm not sure what this book reads like in other languages, but in Vietnamese, sometimes it feels like a cryptic rambling on of a half-crazed ex-soldier. There are flashes of interesting details about war, then mundane & boring description of how the person is in his daily life after the war. Having read and been impressed by All Quiet on the Western Front before, I was feeling a bit down, as in "This is interesting, but how can people compare this to that?"

Only when I got near the end, and closed the last page of the book, did it finally wash over me, the whole feeling of loss and sorrow and dread and tragedy that is a war. And boy, that was powerful. Suddenly I feel like I understand why people like this book, even though I can't exactly explain why. May I just say "yes, now I can feel the sorrow of war, and for someone to be able to convey that deepest and vaguest of feeling to a stranger, it must have been one heck of a book"?

One thing I like about this book, and which explains (to me) why this is considered in the same league of (and not supplanted by) "All Quiet...", is that this is a different kind of wars. We'd think all wars are the same at its core, which is true. But each war also has its unique character. You go through a different setting, and feel a different way when you go through a war between equals, like in "All Quiet...". You go through a different kind of scenes and feelings when you're in a vastly imbalanced (in terms of material and killing power) war, like what the main character here had to go through. The terror is magnified.

Good book for a serious, somewhat heavy read. (less)

The Vietnam War is a very difficult subject for me. Politically, horribly, divisively and invasively, it dominated my coming of age. I have read The Things They Carried by Tim O'Brien, which I thought excellent, but I could read no others. I tried to watch the PBS special but couldn't continue it. This book, however, is truly extraordinary. It is a story of ten years of war by one who survived it on the Vietcong side â€“ with â€œsurviveâ€ being a dubious term and the substance of this book. If you want to understand PTSD, this book shows its formation and strangle-hold better than any other. It is not an easy read for two reasons: one is the brutal subject matter. Science tells us it takes five minutes of war to irreparably change the brain. What would ten constant years do? The second is that it is not written in a chronological manner (neither was O'Brien's). The denouement is actually something that happens first, but you will not know that until the end. There were some paragraphs I reread more than once to extract some meaning from their sense of time. The last three pages I'm still trying to figure out. I'm tempted to say the author should not have done what he did, but he is so good that I don't believe I should take his last three pages lightly. This book was also necessary for me to read to see the â€œother side,â€ the other point of view. That alone was amazing and deeply enlightening. It took three days of thinking about it, and the writing of this review, for the tears to finally come. (less)

While this book is an important piece of literature, I had difficulty understanding the message the author was trying to convey. Parts of the book seemed to be from his perspective, while others are from another soldier, Kien. Throughout the entire book, I was confused whether or not this tale was meant to be fiction or non-fiction. At first, I thought Ninh was using a pseudonym "Kien" for himself; however, towards the end of the book, the narrator claims to have found Kien's manuscript and published it, which I later found out was also false because the entire story is fictional. All of this, combined with other instances of uncertainty, lead to me not trusting the narrator or understanding what he was trying to imply. The timeline is sporadic, the narration is off-putting, and trying to figure out which character I should sympathize with was difficult, to say the least.

Wartime novels are never very easy to judge, even less so when you can't get through the entire thing. I remember my parents questioning, since I was very little and got a nightmare from something I'd read in a book or seen in a movie, why they put bad and scary things in media when so much of it exists in real life anyway?

The truth is that it's natural to have an aversion to bad things, so we're reluctant and have to be 'strong' and 'prepared' for when we read something unpleasant. We don't pick up books like this for fun, but to learn something, which is probably one of the reasons the authors of such works put them out in the first place. We don't enjoy the harsh realities, but they are there, and for people who experience them, it's comforting to know that someone else understands.

For someone like me though, who has never experienced a war firsthand or been exposed to the horrible psychological traumas that characters like Kien have gone through, how can I relate and be interested, when really, I'm just bored?

I applaud the author for making his book what it is, I truly do. However, that does not make it relevant to me, and therefore I cannot judge it any further than this. (less)

Bao Ninh's fictional retelling of the life of a North Vietnamese soldier before, during, and after the Vietnam war is truly a masterpiece, and, I would argue, one of the best war stories ever written. Ninh's retelling thrusts his readers into the minds of his main character and urge you to empathize with the ways in which war changes everything.

Though this book is contextualized around the Vietnam War, it's import goes far beyond. This book reminds readers of the damages war has on everyone involved - civilians and victors included - and that the sorrow that accompanies war will never be able to return you to the pre-war beauty of the past. This is the second time I have read The Sorrow of War (1991) by Bao Ninh. In the Pham Ngu Lao area of Ho Chi Minh City I dined for lunch at La Cantina, a Mexican restaurant of sorts. One of the usual vendors came by carrying a stack of books. Having a beer at midday, I rummaged among the black market books. I came across an English translation of The Sorrow of War (1993) and opened it up. I began reading. Reading more as the woman placed her load on the table. What I read was sadness entire. What I read was beautiful. What I read was poetry and music. I purchased the black market copy for roughly $2 usd, and found a few of the pages out of order or missing. I finished the book any way. So after a year, (purchasing a valid copy this time from Amazon.com) I wanted to return to this story of innocent love and savage loss in times before, during, and after the Vietnam War.

Although The Sorrow of War is fiction, along the lines of A Farewell to Arms or All Quiet on the Western Front, it is a story of war told by a soldier. Bao Ninh served the North with the Glorious 27th Youth Brigade, and of over five hundred soldiers who went to war in 1969, Bao is one of only ten that survived.

The Sorrow of War tells of a young man, age 17, named Kien from Hanoi who falls in love with Phuong, a childhood sweetheart, and how war ultimately corrupts their love.

The novel is fragmented and pieced together. By the end of the novel the reader is told that Kien left the manuscript to a mute woman and vanished. A neighbor, a fellow soldier that remembers Kien, gets the pages and pieces the book back together and publishes the fragments as best he can. The story does jump around from postwar, prewar, and during war times, but the leaps and bounds only flow smoothly in to each other and helps shape the story of Kien and Phuong all the more.

Twenty years after the war, Kien sets out to write a novel. "Kien seems to write only to rid himself of his devils...He continues his quest for perfection, crossing out, erasing, crossing out again, editing, tearing up some pages, then tearing up and destroying all. Then he starts over again, making out each syllable like a learner trying to spell a new word" (pg. 49).

And Kien's story unfolds the horrors of a soul that has seen so much war:

"That autumn was sad, prolonged by rain. Orders came for food rations to be sharply reduced. Hungry, suffering successive bouts of malaria, the troops became anemic and their bodies broke in ulcers, showing through worn and torn clothing. They looked like lepers, not heroic forward scouts. Their faces looked moss-grown, hatched and sorrowful, without hope. It was a stinking life" (pg. 16).

"The uprush of so many souls penetrated Kien's mind, ate into his consciousness, becoming a dark shadow overhanging his own soul. Over a long period, over many, many graves, the souls of the beloved dead silently and gloomily dragged the sorrow of war into his life" (pg. 25).

"But war was a world with no home, no roof, no comforts. A miserable journey of endless drifting. War was a world without real men, without real women, without feeling. War was also a world without romance" (pg. 31).

"No. The ones who loved war were not the young men but the others like the politicians, middle-aged men with fat bellies and short legs. Not the ordinary people. The recent years of war had brought enough suffering and pain to last them a thousand years" (pg. 75).

"The sorrow of war inside a soldier's heart was in a strange way similar to the sorrow of love. It was a kind of nostalgia, like the immense sadness of a world at dusk. It was a sadness, a missing, a pain which could send one soaring back into the past. The sorrow of the battlefield could not normally be pinpointed to one particular event, or even one person. If you focused on any one event it would soon become a tearing pain" (pg. 94).

And there a several graphic scenes, like the one to follow, in this novel, a true novel of sorrow. The scene takes place on April 30, 1975, Victory Day, at Tan Son Nhat Airport near Saigon:

"Enraged, he grabbed the corpse by one leg and dragged her across the floor and down the stairs. Her skull thudded down the steps like a heavy ball. When he reached the concrete floor at the bottom of the stairs, he braced himself, lifted the dead girl, and threw her out into the sunshine next to the another pile of dead southern commandos. The body bounced up, her arms spread wide, and her mouth opened as if she was about to cry out. Her head dropped back with another thud on the concrete. The lout walked away jauntily, swinging his arms as if her were a hero" (pg. 102).


But there are also beautiful scenes that break one's heart when set next to the grief of war. This next scene reminds me a great deal about Vietnam; and when modernity finally comes to Vietnam and there are no more power outages, scenes like this will surely be missed:

"On summer evenings when there were power blackouts and it was too hot inside, everyone came to sit out in front, near the only water tap servicing the whole three-story building.

"The tap trickled, as drop by drop every story was told. Nothing remained secret. People said that Mrs. Thuy, the teacher widowed since her twenties, who was about to retire and become a grandmother, had suddenly fallen in love with Mr. Tu, the bookseller living on the corner of the same street. The two old people had tried to hide their love but had failed. It was true love, something that can't be easily hidden" (pg. 60-61).

The Sorrow of War is a tale of sorrow, lost loves, lost friends, and should be read knowing that not every book has a happy ending. A strong recommend.

This book covers all of the themes familiar from well-known war novels from Storm of Steel to A Rumor of War, though there is real value in seeing the Vietnam war, so often dissected and described from the US soldiers' perspective, being described almost identically from the North Vietnamese soldier's perspective. The horrors of the weather and the jungle were as awful for the NVA as for the Americans; the Americans were perceived as able to slip quietly through the jungle, just as they have described the NVA; the Americans were perceived as almost superhuman and mythologized as predators (especially black American soldiers). Just like their American counterparts, the NVA felt like pawns of bureaucrats, saw the horrors and ugliness of war, questioned the war's purpose, and watched in dismay as young men were cut down peremptorily and people were stripped of their dignity and humanity in the name of amorphous political gains. *SPOILER ALERT* The book begins with a young man determined to go to war, seeing in enlistment both honor and valor. Before he even gets to the front, though, he crashes into reality. Having missed his troop train during his good-bye tryst with his girlfriend, he ends up in a nightmarish sequence of events as he tries to catch up with it. His girlfriend is viciously gang-raped, he kills a sailor with a pipe, they walk through piles of corpses, steal a dead person's bicycle only to sell it later to a man burdened by a sleeping woman, and end up among more soldiers who convince the young man that his girlfriend -- who's still bleeding from the rape, shell-shocked, and actually bathing -- is having sex with their friends. He abandons her there, entirely (and unfairly) disenchanted, and finally makes his way to what's left of his unit, which has had its own shocking entry into war. That night draws a bright line between his childhood and his adulthood, leaving him yearning ever after for an idealized and innocent past -- his own and his country's. The sorrow of war is this loss, the endless suffering of having experienced war, the meaninglessness of both war and peace, the complete and useless erasure of so many individuals, and the loss of community and social fiber as people become focused on only their own survival. Ninh describes the ugliness of war in detail. There is one unforgettable scene in which the protagonist leaves an injured southern soldier in a ditch to seek help, only to realize he can't find that one ditch again, among many. Meanwhile, the rain is falling, filling each ditch in the field to the rim, guaranteeing that the injured southern soldier has drowned. As for politics, there is one remarkable criticism of Marxism but there are many notable critiques of post-war Vietnam as falling far short of the paradise for which the soldiers were fighting. It is described as a disappointment, as a bland and colorless landscape of peace without the charm of the pre-war country. This is foreshadowed by the protagonist's father's paintings, which become more monochromatic and bleak as the country's leadership promotes a cheerful, nationalistic, communist future. The author is describing what IklÃ© explained in Every War Must End as a Pyrrhic victory, in which the North "lost the peace." As in most war books, Ninh's treatment of women is mostly secondary to the needs of the men -- women and girls are victimized, raped, idealized, lusted after, and killed. They are soldiers' playthings, from the dead woman whose naked corpse is mistreated to the rural girls who are first loved by northern soldiers and then raped and killed by southern ones. Even when they have agency, the women suffer, as does one heroic young woman who is gang raped as she draws away American troops to save a group of injured northern soldiers; the protagonist's girlfriend, who was gang raped early on, only to be called a whore and then abandoned by her boyfriend, later does become a prostitute. The book's style is inconsistent and disjunctive, jerking back and forth through time and telling stories from the protagonist's perspective and then the author's. This is also a conceit of the novel, which describes the book in the book as the pieced together product of an abandoned manuscript that itself was written in bursts. Finally, the protagonist seems fixated with impotence -- sexual and general -- and reference to it pervades the book. That this, too, is a sorrow of war is perhaps the book's most unique contribution to the literature. (less)

At first I tried to rearrange the manuscript pages into chronological order, to make the manuscript read like sort of book I was familiar with. But it was useless. There was no chronological order at all. Any page seemed like the first, any page could have been the last. Even if the manuscript had been numbered, even if no pages had been burned, or moth-eaten, or withheld by the author, if by chance they were all there, this novel would still be a work created by turbulent, even manic inspiration.

â€œI envied his inspiration, his optimism in focusing back on the painful but glorious days. They were caring days, when we knew what we were living and fighting for and why we needed to suffer and sacrifice.
Those were the days when all of us were young, very pure, and very sincere.â€
.
A tormenting recollection of anecdotes that gradually scurries between three different timelines: the eleven years of harrowing war and the others, before and after it. The narrator, Kien, full of naivete and innocence is deranged from his normal life as a teenage schoolboy to the horrific war fronts. Bit by bit, the appalling circumstances around him sever his civil subsistence and individuality. Down the line and now a Noth-Vietnamese veteran, he decides to pen down the reminiscence of his experiences in turn evoking a strong emotional response. As he tries to make sense of the eleven years of his life he has given to the senseless war, he finds himself in complete chaos. The thematic feature of his writing is his relationship with his childhood love, Phuong. Their story is moving and sketched in its extremes - filled with all the love, heart, and tenderness or charged with violence and ferocity.
The sequence of events takes the flow of an unstructured narrative, almost like a disconcerted rambling of a person half-awake, nonetheless much like the narrator himself and his life. Despite the inconsequential flow, the sequence itself is effortlessly poignant with rich imagery and compelling representations. From beginning to end, the story flows as discrete episodes. One event here, disarrayed, then the second sequence of events, disruption again, and then some third cluster of events that were described previously. And again, despite it all, it sways you with its flow, gripping you tight and moving you with it.
This is a book Iâ€™ll for sure re-read, a book that should be highly recommended, widely acclaimed, much appreciated, and forever remembered.

Anthony Bourdain mentioned this book in his own book, A Cook's Tour, claiming he read the whole thing in one sitting while sunbathing on a beach in Vietnam. He explained that the horror of the aftermath that Vietnam still physically and emotionally shows was something he had a hard time grasping the reality of until he actually saw it himself. So, what better idea than to read a super depressing North Vietnamese account of how those horrors tore a man's life apart while sitting on a beach in a country where those horrors took place? I guess it doesn't make me any better of a person because I also read this book, sans a vacation to North Vietnam. I just saved my reading time for before bed so my dreams would be nice and terrifying.

The Sorrow Of War was a bit of a challenge in the beginning. My first impression was that this book didn't really know what direction it wanted to go in. Instead of being a solid story from front to back, it broke down into almost mini-stories of accounts of the main character as he journeyed through war. And to make matters more confusing, those accounts were not in any sort of chronological order. But Ninh soon either got the hang of it well enough to play the whole scatterbrain thing as a nifty little writing style, or he actually meant to do it for effect. I would assume it's the latter because he makes mention toward the end about how the writing in the book didn't seem to follow any sort of timeline.

The book gets more and more gruesome as it proceeds, so if you get your rocks off reading about shitty ways to die, and you don't feel like peeling through 1,000 page Game Of Thrones books, you can pick this novel up and read about actual terrible ways people died in a real war. I don't know whether it was the tank driver's first person description of how it felt to roll over fields of dead bodies, or the detailed account of the sound a dead whore's head makes as it bounces off of concrete steps, but it really touched my heart to know that such obscene and stomach-churning details weren't lost on Ninh's end after his personal experience with war.

If that doesn't sound most appealing (or appalling? The difference is only a letter or two!), just remember that there is tons to learn. You'll become familiar with T54's (tanks), AR15's (guns), and almost theatrical visions of bodies being ripped apart, trains being blown up, women being gang-raped, dogs being shot multiple times in the face, and just how fucked up warfare became during the American presence in Vietnam. Brain Technicolor at it's finest and all of a sudden, Ninh's novel becomes the reminder that being able to sit on your couch and read his book is a hell of a lot better than suffering through what those guys had to handle. The book is impactful and both mind-opening and mind-altering.

As far as I know, there are no other published accounts of the Vietnam war from the perspective of a North Vietnamese soldier. So, on that assumption, I am going to say that this book hit it on the mark as close to the real thing as possible. With nothing to compare to, that is not too bold of a statement to make, but, accountability is like swimming with sharks- I'm not going to do it unless you force me. Bao Hinh wrote a fine novel and, while I don't believe Anthony Bourdain sat on a beach and read this thing from cover to cover, mainly because everyone needs a PB&J sandwich break while on the beach all day, I do think he probably came close. This book was originally published under a title in Vietnamese that translates to â€œThe Destiny of Loveâ€ (thanks, Wikipedia!). That is an equally appropriate title for this book--unexpected when I picked this up.

This book is what I needed to read after Fields of Fire left a bad taste in my mouth*. It is a calm collection of the sorrow of war, the destiny of love, the hauntings of life, bending back and forth between pre-war days, war days, post-war days, and the currentish life of â€œThe Writer.â€

Sorrows shares the blunt look at war with Dispatches, but moves its stare away from just the passive observation and disgusted resignation of Herr (great book, not throwing it in the shade) as Ninh follows the ripple of trauma and loss moving forward and backwards in our main man and NVA soldier Kienâ€™s life. Thereâ€™s more hope here than in Herr as well: life in peacetime, no matter how pocked by the sorrows, is still a life of beauty.

Where Iâ€™ve seen some Vietnam war books focus on the strange twinning of exhilaration and fear, this one deals a lot with the guilt and joy of surviving--Kien is the only survivor left of almost all of his different groupings during the war, and in the personal world almost less changed than his childhood love by the war. Still, in one scene two of Kienâ€™s friends are killed near the end of the war, as they raid Saigon, and he runs from the carnage with sadness and joy.

There is a lot of violence, some of it sneaking by, some of it the centerpiece. There is a lot of sexual violence, filtered always through Kien, sometimes so much so that the victims begin to feel props themselves--this is the one part of the book I really struggled with as a reader, but Iâ€™m interested in other peopleâ€™s thoughts.

The big easy takeaway though: different sides, same shit. That one seems almost too obvious to even state, especially after reading this, but for anyone that needs a reminder, here it is.

*I have nothing personal against the book, and I think it'd be distasteful for me to sit on my peace time throne and throw stones at Jim Webb, but it read like it was written to the military/cop fiction genre rather than from experience, which is totally fine but just left me feeling tired and depleted.

Well, I already spent a decent amount of time writing what I believe was an intelligent review of this novel, and technology foiled my master plan. So here I am, on a different computer, but without the energy to re-write my review!

Sigh. ("I know! I know, what a pain!...Shut up already!!!") --->tee he he, I love this book.

Okay, well anyways. This is a delightful novel (that was banned in Vietnam until 1986). A very satirical piece written by VÅ© Trá»ng Phá»¥ng in the 1930's colonial era of Vietnam. You don't have to have a great knowledge of Vietnamese history to fully enjoy Dumb Luck, but you probably should not skip Peter Zinoman's introduction contained if that is the case. This was a re-read for me, as I read this book 6 years ago while living in Vietnam. I loved it then, while immersed in the history and culture and language, and I love it now, even though I retain about 10 words in Vietnamese.

Three points from the introduction that I think are paramount in understanding the satire:
1. In the decade preceding Phá»¥ng's writing of Dumb Luck, the population of Hanoi doubled.
2. Phá»¥ng was part of the first generation of students to be taught exclusively in French. The writing system had just been changed from Chinese lettering to romanized lettering, rendering all previous Vietnamese works unreadable to the new academia.
3. Vietnam at the time was obsessed with Europeanization.

Everything in this novel is so absurd and unbelievable that it makes you laugh. The main character, Red-haired Xuan, makes me want to pull my own hair out because he is so unlikable, yet keeps ending up at point B with more money and fame. Dumb Luck continues to befall to him at the expense of other equally outrageous characters--Mr. and Mrs. Civilization, Mr. High School Graduate, Mr. King of Venereal Disease Treatment, et al. The names are just great.

One of the main themes that arises again and again is on clothing. So much of the novel is spent on the style of dress, and women modernizing their "look". It is ironic because you can cover a person, a community a country with all the French clothing that you want, but if you demand change simply for the sake of change, then all your priorities are backwards.

This is a book of backwards priorities (i.e. "We're policemen, for goodness sake! Our concern is tickets, not laws!") and farce (i.e. "He was overcome with a sensation of happiness and relief, commonly felt among people who succeed in forcing others to marry against their will"), and I recommend it to anyone, which I don't often do.

"I know! I know, what a pain!...Shut up already!!!" Okay. (less)

2.5/5
Modern women who were not virtuous were also not a problem, especially for men who thought of women as toys...A problem only occurred when those toys were one's own sister and wife.
Once again, I tackle a genre that I have poor luck with in a language that is one of the further removed from my fluency in English and spatterings of knowledge in French, German, and Japanese. Don't get me wrong, there's a lot to get out of this book, enough that it doesn't surprise me how long it was banned for in its home country. However, I would have had a better time had I took up a nonfictional book written in line with this work's introduction's theme, because when it comes to playing off of the anachronistic hypocrisies that comes from colonial culture clash, there's satire, and then there's the obviousness of the author having been recently dumped by one woman or another and not getting over it. There are instances where the hapless protagonist gets drawn away from that concern and really gets into the marrow of the absurdities of the social scramble in the new age of democracy, sports, and the god of finance when one's country is owned by another, but it all eventually gets sucked back into cougar-spoofing, hypersexualization, and maybe sorta rape glorification, so trigger warning for all that. Still, the number of white Anglo people on this website who have read a Vietnamese novel that has nothing to do with the Vietnam War (and I mean Vietnamese as in actually Vietnamese, not the latest tragedy porn put out by some white dude who went out on payroll to murder and came back all sad because of it) is dismally small, so anything they can get is better than nothing.

This work probably reads vastly better in French, considering the puns and straight up direct superimposition of French phonetics onto Vietnamese pronunciation. Indeed, The Lover came to mind sometime during my read: not for any thematic similarity, but just for the vastly different perspectives and experiences that the authors had in the same area of the world around a similar time. Duras was in Vietnam/French Indochina from 1914 to 1931, the country that VÅ© Trá»ng Phá»¥ng spent most of, if not all, of his life in from 1912 to 1939, publishing this work in 1936. If one wants a glimpse of yet another instance of imperial democracy, one of the most horrific anachronisms to be invented by the civilized world, this is one of the shorter and more sensational texts one could delve into: I'm sure this work holds some kind of record for speaking so frankly about venereal disease, among other topics. The best bits are the ones concerning social engineering, where a corporate magnate makes bank off of owning the brothels as well as the hospitals, and secret service underlings negotiate the difference between Imperial France and Fascist Siam in order to prevent anyone getting pissed off and starting World War II (the king of Siam's German and Japanese advisors hint at the inevitability of such nonetheless, something that the author didn't live long enough, whether for good or for ill, to witness for himself). So, interesting times, to say the least, and as someone who had her interesting times officially extended for another month, at least, I can't really fault the author for being so fed up about it in his writing. Leastwise, not that much.

I realized while writing this up that this wasn't sounding much like a two star review, which goes to show one of the many benefits of the post-read review in action. Reading this didn't make me keen on tracking down the author's other works, but I do marvel at the fact that I became interested in this kind of book way back near beginning of my GR (before it became GRAmazon at any rate) career and even managed to track down a copy within three years of adding it (person of color + translation + older than 1950 usually means six years at minimum). In any case, this makes for four read works by three actual Vietnamese authors writing in Vietnamese, and I have some anthologies and another full novel on hand before I'm completely out of stock. Certainly not a great track record, even when only considering my readings in translation, but if there's one thing I've learned when pursuing the reads beyond the customary mainstream, it's that I'm off bemoaning my paltry deep see diving levels while most other are still at the stage of dipping in a single toe, if that. So, I'll just have to be glad that there's another sector of the world that I really need to read up more on in both the fiction and nonfiction senses of the word, and leave others to determine whether this author, one who has been repeatedly compared to Balzac (for whatever that's worth) is worth their time.

I don't know much about 1930s Hanoi to offer any real commentary on Dumb Luck, but it was an interesting look into late-colonial Vietnam, and an intriguing introduction to Vu Trong Phung, a controversial and prolific writer in the Vietnamese canon. It's pretty obvious Vu was disturbed by the vast changes that were sweeping Vietnamese society in the country's bid for modernization. This unease translates to the blistering satire on display in Dumb Luck, which follows the farcial rise of streetrat Red Xuan to the upper-echelons of this society obsessed with "Europeanization". This all sounds rather dry, but Dumb Luck is for the most part very funny, as Vu keen observations paint a throughly absurd landscape, one that is best illustrated through quotes...

On the police, who are obsessed with meeting their fining quotas, and on the verge of being forced to fine each other: "Out on the street a car pulled up in front of the station. Mrs. Deputy Customs Officer entered the front office and smiled at the officers, who smiled back like merchants greeting a rich customer. Because [she] often let her dog loose, she had been ticketed at least once on each of the precinct's sixteen streets. To the police, in other words, she was like a regular customer of a failing business."

On artists: "... you are a journalist. Your duty is to help enhance the knowledge of the common people so that one day they too may understand art. I, on the other hand, am an artist. I am much too busy devoting myself to art to explain my work to them... The more difficult a work of art is to understand, the more valuable it is. For example, in Italy and in Germany, I hear, those painters whose works are completely incomprehensible are worshiped as saints. When the dictators Hitler and Mussolini took power, they were so jealous of these artists that they threw them in jail. I only pray that someday our artists will be good enough to be thrown in jail as well!"

On cross-class romances: "After several months they invariably jump together into one of the lakes. Initially, most people jumped into West Lake, but, because it was very deep, few of those who attempted suicide survived. Hence, people eventually skirted to the more shallow and less dangerous White Bamboo Lake... Night after night idle ricksaw pullers and jobless young men who could swim loitered around the bands of the lake... expectantly for a heart-rending and plaintive 'Save me!' whereupon they would dive in the waters and fish out a beautiful girl. Next stop was the Hang Dau Police Station, where they would receive a monetary award, pose for newspaper photos, and sit through numerous noisy interviews. As a result, White Bamboo Lake became an important setting for those awful tragedies staged regularly in Hanoi during which the evil Vietnamese family conspires to prevent free marriage, free divores, free remarriage, and so on."

In the world of Dumb Luck, public institutions (government) have become businesses, businesses package the trappings so-called progressive social movements for sale, and people who buy into these "values" act only facetiously. Vuâ€™s harshest, and perhaps most prescient, warning is of the dangers of adopting capitalistic culture (where even values are sold and advertised) instead of merely the capitalistic economic system.

Vu is particularly interested in the role of women in this new society, and his thesis is best illustrated in a subplot in a modern dress shop. The designer there, who sells outfits named for their effects, such as "Promise" and "Resolute Faithfulness" ("for widows determined to honor their late husbands and remain unmarried") and "Hesitation" ("for widows who are less determined"), touting their ability to liberate women from the outside in, on seeing his own wife at the shop: "Shut up, you idiot! Don't you known that there are different kinds of women? When we campaign for the reform of women, we mean other people's wives and sisters, not our own! Don't you understand? It's one thing for other women to reform, but you're my wife. Of course, I would never permit you to become one of those modern women!"

Now that does seem rather applicable to the here and now, doesn't it? How many products are sold to women based not on their real benefits but on the messages of "improve yourself", "love yourself" and other liberations of the "you're not good enough yet, but don't worry, you can buy self-esteem from us" variety? Rating: 4 stars (less)

Just about every sector has been turned towards self-commodification. From the police:

to the Buddhist monks:

This is the story of the Red-haired Xuan and his absurd and impossible rise from a street vagabond to a respected member of the pretentious European worshiping society. Well, that is the superficial story, but in fact what this is is a blackly humorous, beautifully written social commentary that is as acidic as hydrochloric acid. Banned in it's native Vietnam until 1986 I was quite fascinated to read a book that had been banned. The rhetoric of Hanoi when I was there was very heavily communistic propaganda in many ways and I was agog to see what the banned book could have to say.

I won't lie; three times I tried to read this and was completely defeated. I could not catch the tone of the writing, I did not understand what the characters were meant to be nor what the author was trying to give me. Finally, this last time I started by reading the introduction by the scholarly Peter Zinoman, and suddenly it all fell into place. If anyone is contemplating reading this book, I really, REALLY recommend starting with the introduction! Here, we are introduced to the clash of cultures that was occurring in Hanoi of the 1930's and the explanation of Phung's heavily conservative attitude and his street background enables the reader (me) to understand where the signature character is coming from.

With the benefit of this background, I could see and thoroughly enjoy the acerbic attitude to discarding tradition and family in a ruthless attempt to change the urban social order. the text is very rich, and it is a masterful translation which lets you see this, because Vietnamese, when translated into English, can, at times, come across as basic and naive. In this book however the complexities of the language and society unfold subtly, so that by the end of the book I was kind of in awe of the writing.

The satire is so sharp it cuts, the cast of characters is given a range of names that are almost their designations, or descriptions rather than simple names. So, we have Mr and Mrs Civilization, Mrs Deputy Customs Officer and others who are exemplifying aspects of the author's Vietnam while their own arrogance and stupidity brings our hero to the fore of their society without every really trying.

Having bought this book while I was in Hanoi it was an added pleasure while reading to have some acquaintance with the country which was it's source. While I do not for a second doubt that the Hanoi of the 1930's in which it was written is vastly different to the Hanoi of today, I think having visited there helped me catch the cadence and perhaps some of the cultural background to make the book even more interesting than it otherwise would be.

The one thing about it that I was a little uncomfortable with was that traditional Vietnam, much like China, had this quaint and horrible notion that widows should not remarry. Once a woman's husband dies, her life is essentially over, though she is allowed to dedicate herself to any existing children. This 'traditional' attitude was the one the author's own widowed mother took and without the introduction explaining the author's background I might have found this a bit repellent. As it was however, it was merely interesting.

The impetus of literature to resonate the repercussions of a nation's history, particularly the people's struggles and aspirations which metamorphosed into cries of rebellion, is evident in Vu Trong Phung's novel "Dumb Luck". This biting satire, published by the University of Michigan Press 66 years after its initial and controversial publication in Vietnam, expounded on the clash between conservatism and Europeanization in the Annamese society. This is perhaps the most straightforward nover I've ever read - no more allegories, no more predestination paradoxes, no more imagined communities whatsoever - as it enumerated tidbits of history which disturbed, and eventually enlightened, the rest of Southeast Asia.

All the characters were given genuine individualities. However, Phung's intention to baptize authorities and elitist families into objects of societal ridicule has always been manifested between chapters. The influential Vietnamese novelist, who died three years after the novel's publication, involved himself in the narrative process, using expressions such as "our king" and "our emperor" upon explicating the inhibitions and trickery of the well-loved protagonist Red-Haired Xuan.

For those who always find joy in reading novels explicitly containing ideological content, this is a must-read.

Rest assured, through this work of art, Phung had proven what Roberto BolaÃ±o had said: The two things are connected, writing and destroying, hiding and being found. (less)

Vu Trong Phung to Vietnamese society is like Natsume Soseki for the Japanese. Red-haired Xuan has become the new voice of a generation in Vietnam, just like Botchan is in Japan. It is a story about a changing society. From the old one to a new one. From feudalistic into modern. From backward to progressive.

Vu has successfully captured the moment as Vietnam is changing rapidly due to various colonial policies introduced by the French in Indochina. How a generation began to abandon writing in Chá»¯ NÃ´m, the old characters derived from the Chinese Hanzi, into incorporating Quá»‘c ngá»¯, the romanised version of Vietnamese using Latin characters. Suddenly a new generation could not be able to read the literature written in the previous decades. They are heavily reformed, through a new way of thinking thanks to the modernisations.

This is a nostalgic book, which I personally think everyone who has read â€œBotchanâ€ by Natsume Soseki would be able to relate. It tells a story about a not fully changed society which struggled to incorporate new identities to itself. A society which is not sure yet about new identities to choose. Whether to fully abandon the old one, or still keeping it.

It is shown clearly in the story on how even in the process of modernisation itself, there are still some resistance even from the agents of modernisation itself. The character Mr. ILL (I Love Ladies), clearly illustrates how he has been trying to bring modernity by advocating the Europeanised-style clothes. Dumb luck follows the fortunes of an orphaned Vietnamese man named Red Haired Xuan. Following his dismissal from his job for spying on changing women, he is fortuitously employed as an ambassador for the Europeanization movement of Indochina. Xuan, through his quick thinking and good fortunes, rises through the social ranks astronomically and eventually has a hand in the important affairs of a prominent middle-class family, seemingly all from his dumb luck. The novel deals with the themes of social hierarchy, stressing that almost every decision one of the main characters make is for the purposes of advancing their own name within the social ecosystem, or saving face to prevent a social fall.
The novel was written by Vu Trong Phung in 1936 and heavily satirises the characters which it represents. As a result of its social commentary, it was banned by the ruling communist party in Vietnam from 1960 until 1975. Despite its cultural significance, the novel has won no major awards and was only published in English for the first time in 2002. However, it is considered a classic in Vietnam and is studied by school children in the country. One could certainly see a film or television adaptation being created from the novel as the characters really do come across as captivating and entertaining.
The novel is set in Hanoi, the capital in the north of the country. This is to highlight the emerging middle class in the country due to French colonization, a middle class which would not have existed still in the more rural areas. Many of the important characters within the story fall into this category of the emerging middle class. However, the author has given them nicknames rather than traditional names. For example, there is a Mr and Mrs Civilisation, who own the Europeanization tailor shop. There is a Mr ILL, which stands for â€˜I Love Ladiesâ€™. These characters are all primarily concerned with how the new society views them and their attempts at Europeanization are simply to increase their own reputations, in my view. The elders within the family that Xuan finds himself helping seem to be wrestling with internal conflict, they are enjoying the fame and fortune of being an important family yet still wish to hold onto traditional Vietnamese marriages, like objecting to premarital sex.
I would certainly recommend this book for teen or adult readers, there are lots of subtle ironies and jokes that may not be understood or fully by children reading this novel. But for that reason, its comedy and wit, I would steer those interested towards this book, it is worth the investment.

Originally published in 1936, this Vietnamese satirical novel follows the adventures of a poor ball-boy at a Hanoi tennis club, who, through an ongoing series of shenanigans and misunderstandings, rises to dizzying success in society. It's a familiar-enough trope -- the wily commoner who turns the fads and prejudices of the bourgeois to his own advantage. In this instance, our hero deftly uses the country's rush to urbanize, "modernize" and "Europeanize" to enhance his wealth, status, fame, and love life. 

Unfortunately, it's only mildly amusing, and often quite tedious. The book originally appeared in serialized form in a Hanoi newspaper, and certain phrases, jokes, and setups are repeated again and again across different installments/chapters, making for some very repetitive gags. Aspects of the satire definitely feel daring for its time, for example, those pertaining to sex and religion, but a little bit of it goes a long way. Probably best appreciated by readers with an strong interest in Vietnam, or literature of the French colonies.  (less)
