This fictional account of growing up in Vietnam after the war is often promoted as the first novel from Vietnam ever published in the US, and one that was often banned in its own country. Indeed its author has spent time in jail and definitely expresses anti-communist views in this book, as well as the others in the trilogy.

But it is more than a critical look at the impact Communism had on the lives of ordinary people - people with small shops or a little land - property that was "reclaimed" by the new government and ostensibly redistributed for the good of all, but all too often only for the good of the higher ups in the Party. Huong does explore the reforms that were made several years following the war, and property that was returned.

Huong is a woman, and focuses on how these grand ideas created by men in offices are all too often born out by women in homes and on farms, in small businesses. Property is taken from women; a Party loyal brother insists his sister not marry the love of her life because his family has wealth - splitting up the couple even though she is already pregnant with his daughter (who becomes the protagonist). The resultant daughter (Hang) becomes a pawn - the Party loyalist Uncle wants to use her (literally) to promote his Communist ideals, as she becomes an export worker in Moscow. Her aunt (whose brother fathered Hang) loves her dearly and sacrifices greatly to ensure Hang is educated but wants her to continue the old ways, keeping all the traditions alive. Hang's own mother also has almost zero agency in her own life - losing the man she loves, losing a leg, losing her business, left to sell a few candies out of a window to try to feed herself and her daughter.

So there is much here - feminism, anti-communism, modernism vs tradition, power vs agency. Food.
So much food. You will definitely need to eat some Vietnamese food while reading this book. And yet. . . I didn't love this book. The author is primarily a screenwriter and it shows. Or perhaps it is the translation. It just felt pedantic to me. So much narration - she walked here, turned to her left, set the glass down type thing. For as much drama and emotion should have been here, I never really connected with Hang or Aunt Tam or the tragic mother. I hated Chinh but not deeply. There just wasn't emotional connect - it was just kind of cold, a telling. As is evidence by my "date started and date finished - I put it down for a good six weeks before picking it back up and finishing. My high school seniors are going to be reading this this year - I will be eager to hear what they think. (less)

Grace Paley wrote, "We have been hearing for many years from Americans who seemed to consider the Vietnamese experience -- life and war -- their own. At last a woman, a Vietnamese woman, tells us Vietnamese life: the village, the city, the repression and expansion, the middle peasant, the poor peasant, the years of exquisite food and no food, working in the Soviet Union -- and all beautifully told so that we can begin to understand not where we were for years, but where and how they -- the Vietnamese -- are now."

Paradise of the Blind is the first novel from Vietnam published in the United States, and banned in its own country. Its author, DÆ°Æ¡ng Thu HÆ°Æ¡ng, is a political dissident who has been imprisoned in her own country for her writing and outspoken criticism. I hadn't heard of this novel until the coordinator of the IB Diploma Program sent me a note about it after a coordinator meeting, letting me know that it was a popular choice for Works in Translation, a required component of IB Literature, which I teach. Next year our curriculum is changing and we need to replace three of the current works in translation, so I used this an opportunity to read this novel. I loved it, and I'm excited for the opportunity to teach it. The story is narrated by a young woman named Hang who has left Hanoi to work in the then Soviet Union; she receives a telegram letting her know that her uncle Chinh (who at that time is in Moscow) is very ill, and she must go to him. From there the novel shifts back to Vietnam to unfurl the story of Hang, her mother, and her Aunt Tam; the focus is really on these three women. Hang's mother, Que, is fiercely loyal to her brother Chinh despite his pettiness and greed. Hang's Aunt Tam hates Chinh for causing the death of her brother Ton, Hang's father and the one love of Que's life. Throughout the novel, the women are the ones who make the sacrifices, and the cost is everything.

I love stories that evoke a strong sense of place, and the descriptions of Hanoi are heavy: sensual, beautiful, oppressive. (The descriptions of Russia are also heavy: icy and oppressive.) Food is clearly central to the way people interact with each other, either with generosity or contempt, and I'll just go ahead and admit right now that this book made me hungry. The descriptions of food are among the best and most memorable I've ever read. (less)

I thought this was going to be really good. It was the first novel translated from Vietnamese to English even though it was only published in 1988. That says a huge amount about many things, most of it supposition.

The plot follows the life of Hang, a young woman, in a series of flashbacks and contemporary reflections. We follow her as she studies in Moscow and visiting her ageing uncle there.

As she grows, she discovers what has caused the tensions between her, her mother, her aunt and her uncle, and she fights to keep in play multiple loyalties.

Her childhood has been difficult with an absent father and a mother who has sacrificed everything for her. Thereâ€™s a whole ton of emotional baggage buried beneath the surface, as youâ€™d expect from Vietnam in the 1980s, but while I really wanted an insight into Vietnamese culture and particularly the political issues, I didnâ€™t really get it in the form I was expecting.

I guess I was after docudrama and what I got was the story of one family from the point of view of a active critic of the Communist government.

The fact that Vietnam has banned the book for its political stance surprises me on the one hand because it doesnâ€™t have outright criticism in its pages. But when youâ€™ve lived all your life serving a Communist leadership, you learn, I suppose, to make your case with more subtlety.

This makes the criticism harder to spot in a novel that places what weâ€™re having for dinner and a description of a moonlit night on the same par as what the local communist cadre is up to.

And maybe thatâ€™s the point, that the Party isnâ€™t front and centre, that daily life is more important than political ideology. If so, the novel works a charm.

The storytelling is very fragmented and the characters arenâ€™t developed too much. While this may be frustrating for western readers, it definitely romanticises the beauty of Vietnam and cultural essentials like its food and so, for Vietnamese, I can see how would strike a very melodic chord. (less)

Written in 1988, Paradise of the Blind was the first Vietnamese novel published in the United States (in 1993). Every time I read a translated novel, Iâ€™m amazed by the art that is translation â€” to translate not just the words, but the feelings, the unspoken gestures, and the atmosphere. This was a book where I felt the power of translation very acutely, because the writing had such a specific feel to it: it was so lyrical, melancholy, full of descriptions that I kept associating with a lush pastel palette. I wondered if these were the same feelings the original text would have evoked. Or perhaps what was added in this translation, or lost.

In Paradise of the Blind, Hang and her mother are caught in the ideological chasm that has torn the family apart: on one hand, Hangâ€™s Uncle Chinh is completely devoted to the Communist party, and on the other, her Aunt Tam was denounced by the party and lost her family and her land. This book is an intimate portrait into the messy interplay between survival, materialism, and ideology. It got me thinking about how ideas of being dutiful to your family can slip into unhealthy relationships predicated on giving and giving.

This book is a close-up of just a few characters and included little historical context, but the dynamics between Hang, her mother, Uncle Chinh, and Aunt Tam, are deeply embedded in the bigger political forces in play in 1950s-80s Vietnam. The author, Duong Thu Huong, was expelled from the Communist party the year after she wrote this book and imprisoned briefly. Today, the book remains banned in Vietnam. I feel like thereâ€™s this Western fetishization of books that are banned in their home country, especially if the book is critical of communism, but I also have to admit that this book caught my eye because it is banned. But there are no sides to take in this book, no damning critique of a specific ideology or the other; instead, a quiet, and slightly existential, meditation. (less)

It is the early 1980s and 20-year-old Hang is a Vietnamese â€œexported workerâ€ living in the Soviet Union. As she takes a train journey to Moscow, she reflects on her childhood and her motherâ€™s stories from the time before she was born. In this coming-of-age story, the heroine navigates conflicting and sometimes destructive devotions to both blood lines and the Communist Party.

Paradise of the Blind is a lovely piece of literature, which was banned in Vietnam a year after it was published. I found the bright and loving Hang to be an inspiring character and I loved the ending of the novel. While Huong certainly offers criticism of the Communist Party and of some elements of patriarchy in Vietnamese culture, I appreciated that she did so in a nuanced way and that she also tells a wonderful story beyond just that. This book also provides an interesting glimpse into life in rural and urban Vietnam in the post-US war decades, and explores the bleak impact of some of the more repressive measures taken by the Communist Party in Vietnam.

Huong -- who volunteered on the fronts in Vietnamâ€™s wars with the US and China -- was long disillusioned by the corruption and repression she saw in the Party. This book was published in 1988; in 1989 Huong was expelled from the Party and she also spent time in jail because of her writings. Most (all?) of her books have been banned in Vietnam and her later works have only been published outside her country. (less)

This book is an enlightening look at the way the rise of communism in Vietnam tore families apart and rooted trauma for generations to come. The story follows young Hang, who grew up after the war. Her father was exiled by her uncle, a communist official who returned to his hometown to bring about the new order. Hang's mother feels a responsibility for her brother, even when he tears the family apart. Hang's aunt, her father's sister, is vengeful and pours herself into building her wealth for the last of her family's blood: Hang.

This is a good story, but simple and with limited perspective. I'd recommend this simply because of its historical significance. Huong was, herself, a communist revolutionary and came to change her views when she saw the devastation it brought to families. She was eventually imprisoned for her writing, even after the country encouraged artists to share their true feelings again instead of streamlining them with the state agenda. That, in itself, is amazing.

On its own, it didn't make me feel terribly connected to the characters or their struggle, but a good read nonetheless. (less)

The characters in this novel are real and I can picture them living and breathing right here in Hanoi. Duong Thu Huong is a great writer writing about real Vietnamese people. Her book centers around a Vietnamese girl growing up and left ignorant of much of her own background. Her parents loved each other but in Communist Vietnam their love was dangerous.

Throughout the book Hang, the young girl, has to maneuver her way through the relationships she has with 3 distinct families: her mother, her motherâ€™s brother Uncle Chinh; and her fatherâ€™s sister, Aunt Tam. At times she rejects one or all of these 3 families, particularly as she starts college, but she gets pulled back to each, mainly out of obligation and rarely out of love.

I found it difficult to put the book down in a reading. It is not a â€œbigâ€ book in its scope but it is a big book in covering the social, moral and political woes of the country of Vietnam. The author has been jailed before for her other books. Her truth apparently is dangerous. (less)

Duong Thu Huong takes her reader through a harrowing story of the ways in which revolutionary totalitarianism and communism can tear families and even persons apart. She invites us into the story of Hang, a Vietnamese girl whose parents' marriage is ripped apart by the victory of the communist North Vietnamese. Hang finds herself torn between two competing loyalties: the loyalty of her mother to her brother as family, and the loyalty of her father's sister toward her as the last surviving member of the line.

In the midst of this, we catch a glimpse of the way the revolutionary ideals of the North Vietnamese became tyrannical and repressive, especially to those at the margins of society struggling to make a living: small farmers, street vendors, college students.

In the end, the only hope seems to be leaving behind Vietnam, allegorized as purple flowers growing over a morasse of decay, for other hopeful futures.

Sadly, Huong herself will likely never leave Vietnam, as she has been denied permission to travel despite her multiple awards. A difficult but worthy read. (less)

The story is rich in detail and free of cliche. It depicts the complexity of Vietnamese culture, the symbolic value of food, class distinctions, and conflicts between traditions and ideologies.

Hangâ€™s relationships with other characters symbolises the writer's message. Her relationship with her mom symbolises her uneasiness & criticism with traditional confucian/asian values, while her relationship with her father symbolises her criticism towards communism and corruption. The protagonist led us in reflecting these as she feels conflicted throughout the story, unsure of what to do.

The book is full of metaphors and allegories that wonâ€™t stop our mind to wander & link them, equipped with rich characters with complex emotions and feelings. It also illustrates the rich Viatnamese culture with detailed mentions of foods & its culture.


The title represents how the characters were happily yet blindly following their traditions/patriarchal structures/communist ideologies, without realizing how much suffering they cause harm to oneself and others.

(less)

Growing up in Vietnam during the communist 70s and 80s, young Hang is used to hardships. Her cadre maternal uncle has her father's family classified as landlords (for owning a small paddy). Her father is sent away. Hang is raised alone, by her mother with her paternal aunt's help. Her paternal Aunt Tam can never forgive Hang's father for sending her brother away, most likely to his death. Tam can barely tolerate how Hang's mother continually helps her brother, despite the fact that he ruined her own family's lives. She feeds his kids when he is struggling, even though Hang then suffers lack of food. She sells the inheritance jewelry Tam gave for Hang. Her brother even says her work as a maker and vendor of vermicelli means she is not a real proper peasant.

Hang manages to get to college, but then needs to drop out to help her mother. In this novel we hear many stories of the typical Vietnamese and how they struggle through this time period of uncertainty. (less)

It is a bit of a pity, as there is so much potential in this story. With only 258 pages, this is a short book and the author would have had so much room to go into depth about how the protagonist's relationship with her mother, aunt and uncle evolves and which impact the political system has on the relationships between the individual characters. Instead, the actual plot appears to be secondary and I felt like I was following a character around that was just talking about the food that is being eaten and the ingredients used to prepare the individual dishes. While I primarily read this book because I wanted to learn something about Vietnam and food undeniably is an important and interesting part of every culture, I think the author should have written a separate book on Vietnamese cuisine and filled this one with a story. (less)

This book really magnetizes me despite a little confusion to catch up with the style of the author at first. I felt empathy and helplessness for the painful and lay láº¯t existence of the characters;though
in some period there is a ray of sun and laughing but at large the sadness and the constant feeling of despair pervade the whole story creeping into every corner of Hang's memory.
Que, Hang's mother, spend her energy and tá»‰me trying to bridge the gap with her young brother, but it is also this blood tie that blithely yawns the chasm with her only child. Aunt Tam is my favorite character with a strong and forceful disposition that can dwindle anyone before her and it is the longing for revenge that sustains her after the other members of her family were indirectly killed by Hang's uncle.
The ending is the brightest part after the whole bleak recollection of Hang. (less)

What is it like to be binded by the past while dreaming and reaching for a better future? What is it like to be suffocated by society's beliefs and conventions, doubting whether if there is any meaning left at all in holding onto those things that have gradually been decaying for so long, and yet cannot be so heartless as to reject them entirely. Paradise is where? In the past, in the future, or in somewhere that cannot be fully understood and recognized? The cruelty and hopefulness of life, the cruelty and holiness of human relations and affections. We are a despicable and resilient creature as we all try to navigate and find meanings in this mists of grayness that is called history and humanity.

Very heavy and haunting book, probably one of the best of modern Viet literature that I've read so far. It's a great shame that this book is banned in Vietnam. (less)

this isn't an in-depth review, but this is a wonderfully written novel that essentially denounces the atrocities of the Vietnamese government as Communism begins to take influence. it follows Hang and her life in Vietnam growing up as she witnesses a plethora of events unfold including the brutal effects the Communist regime have on people. Huong is such a talented writer as every sentence in this book is structured in vivid prose, and the story is delicate yet strong. the ending was satisfying, and the symbolism is strong. i wanted to include a quote from the book that, in my opinion, well conveys the overall plot and strengths of the book.
- "I can't squander my life tending these faded flowers, these shadows, the legacy of past crimes."
critical rating: 5/5
personal rating: 4.5/5 (i really enjoyed it!) (less)

Duong Thu Huong is a disappointed idealist and her novel can be considered a criticism of the socialist experiment with its hollow ideological principles filled with corrupt practices and tawdry materialist goods. The novel illustrates how institutions and policy betray their ideals and cripple the human spirit. There is a minor soapbox speech to that effect in the latter part of the novel but the disillusionment is illustrated throughout the text in the form of reminiscences of Hang's childhood in Vietnam. Her memories are recalled during a bleak train journey from a Russian factory town, where she is employed as an itinerant worker, to Moscow where she has been summoned by her uncle.

The young woman's recollections depict the life draining struggle to survive in a workerâ€™s paradise filled with neglect and decay against a background of the vivid natural beauty of the countryside and descriptions involving the preparation of various dishes and their resulting tastes and aromas. Although Iâ€™ve yet to read Babetteâ€™s Feast by Isak Dinesen, I would imagine that Huongâ€™s novel shares some similarities.

The internal drama focuses of how she tries to navigate within the turmoil amongst her immediate family whose behaviors are a consequence of the collision between socialist ideology and a conservative family-oriented agrarian culture. Their irrational responses are motivated by duty, revenge, and humiliation. (less)

Offering a study of Vietnamese women across the 1960s-1980s, Duong's novel moves easily from Saigon to Moscow, tracking the pull of ideology that more and more underscores Vietnamese action at the expense of family ties. Duong situates this within three women's lives, and the uncle/brother who binds them to one another as he invests in strict communistic ideology.

It's a powerful story, though it pulls some of the nationalist punches that Duong later explored in her Novel Without a Name. Still, that one, concerned with loss of innocence in the face of bureaucratic excess, covered men far more, and so this glimpse into women in these conditions is valuable culturally and aesthetically, as the translation captures ease with metaphor and symbolism. (less)

This book portrays the sorrows and disillusionment the average Vietnamese face under the various political reformation events in Vietnam around the 1950s-1980s, through the eyes of the protagonist, Hang. Hang was forced to cut short her education to become an "exported worker" in what was then the Soviet Union. We get to understand Hang's past through her flashback, detailing how the various political reform ripped her family and village apart.

This was a book that I really took my time reading. The tone was melancholy as it portrays humans' despair and suffering. It felt that life was truly unfair, as we went on the journey to Hang's past. We get to see how Hang's character build-up throughout her flashbacks, how she develops her own characteristics and sets her own values. It's one book that really got me to ponder a lot. (less)

Most of the story happens while Hang is on a train, traveling to see her uncle in Moscow. The book cuts between her journey, and moments/memories of her childhood, growing up poor in a tiny village in Vietnam.

Since the timeline isnâ€™t completely linear, and there are gaps (itâ€™s often difficult to determine how much time has passed), I sometimes found it difficult to follow. Also, the book was slow-moving at first, but the characters became more interesting as it went along. I found myself quite invested in Hang, her mother, her aunt, and her uncle, wondering what was going to happen to each of them.

Overall, 3 stars. It was mostly interesting, but not terribly riveting or moving. (less)

Until I was about 75% finished, I was settled firmly on 3-star rating. I felt the book was slow and verbose and less nuanced than I expected for one exploring the political and relational issues at hand. I was fully aware that I may have been missing elements because of the cultural divide.

The last quarter of the book really picks up in terms of empathy and cohesion. The descriptive detail does not lessen, but there are some poignant metaphors and epiphany moments that create a very satisfying conclusion to the rest of the book. As Americans, our knowledge of Vietnam after the early 1970s is sorely lacking. I appreciate this look inside and feel richer for having explored it. (less)

"Paradise of the Blind" is set in Vietnam and written by a Vietnamese author whose works were banned in her own country and who lived under house arrest for quite some time (I believe I read that she is now living outside of Vietnam). Through reminiscing, it tells the story of a young girl and her family who live through the expulsion of the French and eventually of the Americans. Life is not easy for this family, even though the girl's uncle is a communist party official.

It is a rare look into life in North Vietnam (rare for me, anyway), and that alone makes it interesting. The flow seemed a bit disjointed and that made the story difficult to follow at times. I'm still glad I read it. (less)

This was actually a really beautiful story about a daughter and her complicated relationship with her mother and aunt, struggling with socio-economic related problems that are the root of the strained relationships she has with her mother and aunt, as well as the root of her mother's issues with her aunt. This story is a lightly veiled memoir about the author, and her desire to please her mother, succeed in life, and not abandon her family, no matter how shitty her uncle is. It is raw and human and really melancholy, but a fascinating different perspective of a different generation and culture in a different country. (less)

Through Hang's flashbacks, the author offers a political commentary and a wonderful exploration of complex familial relationships and personal development. The imagery is striking and often mouth-watering (sooooo many food descriptions, which was significant in terms of celebrating an important aspect of Vietnamese culture and family life).

It is a beautiful and an extremely important book and while I would definitely recommend it, it was a slow read. Even though the imagery was lovely, I did find some of the exceptionally long descriptions a bit tedious.
3.5 (less)

A good insight for Western readers into life in Vietnam post-war. Although I know what period it refers to, it was almost timeless and could have been written about life 50 or 100 years ago, with the focus on family struggles, the downtrodden life of women, food and festivals, and the absence of modern technology. I would have liked more about how our heroine Hang came to be working in a Russian textile factory.

Even though Paradise of the Blind was an assigned reading, I would read this novel for fun. I have never seen such collective mastery, elegance, and poise in an authorâ€™s writing. Duong Thu Huongâ€™s exceptional grace with rhetoric works to craft a powerful story of Vietnam during the Lao Dong communist regime through the lenses of a fragmented family. At the same time, Huong provides an extraordinary detailed insight into the bonds tying traditional Vietnamese culture. Wonderful read. 5/5

Although I really enjoyed the Vietnamese culture and the sort of more first-hand account of Communism and how it affected everyday people in Vietnam, I got confused by the roundabout chronology of events. I liked this bildungsroman and thought it was well written, but because of the nature of Hang's different stages of life being presented and not really knowing where we are in time at any given moment, that's what ultimately brought it down a star for me. Really great novel. (less)

I appreciated the subtlety of the political aspects of this book. I felt that Thuong did a great job of infusing controversial topics into a realistic plot line whose characters were never good or bad, simply flawed. This is a great book for introducing global concerns whose effects are still felt today.

This book started well, and I looked forward to reading it up until the halfway point. Then it dragged on with some unsuccessful injection of a boring romance. The description on life in Vietnam and the of folly of communism were very interesting. However the story on the protagonist was not. The ending was alright, so all-in all a pretty good read.

Story wise it was a strong perspective into a post war Vietnamese world. The timeline was very confusing as it jumped constantly without giving you any clues. The story had a lot of emotions and characters, but not a lot really happens in the story. It won't be for everyone but I definitely liked it. (less)

A few things:
- Incredible prose.
- The narrative line plays catch-up.
- How DÆ°Æ¡ng Thu HÆ°Æ¡ng ties together the two sides of the family illustrates the internal, domestic conflict that maps onto the political landscape.
- The last scene with Aunt TÃ¢m's death shakes me to the core.
- Competing femininity complicates the entire novel. (less)

I love this book. While visiting Cambodia and Thailand we become more determined to eventually visit Vietnam. Itâ€™s a beautiful part of the world and the people are warm and kind to visitors. This book is about the burden of family expectations, the joy of having someone believe in you, the impact of social unrest on those struggling to survive and so much more. I highly recommend it.

Read this for our book club and like it. To better understand the context of the post Vietnam War setting of the novel, I read a 700 page book of history of Vietnam and learning about the impact of confucianism on the society of Vietnam - especially women - brought this novel more to life. Some of the descriptive passages are lovely.

A book that depicts vividly life in post-land transformation (cai cach ruong dat) in Vietnam. I don't really like how the author builds the villains. They are just straight-up cruel and despicable from the beginning to the end, without any nuances. If you can, read the book in its original language. A lot has been lost in translation. (less)

Duong Thu Huongâ€™s Paradise of the Blind covers the impact of the Communist regime on a family with an effective portrayal of family strife that doesnâ€™t get didactic. Hang is the central character, a North Vietnamese woman we see initially as an â€œexported workerâ€ in the Soviet Union living in a Spartan dormitory. She receives a communication from an uncle in Moscow, a party official, which leads to her decision to take a rail cross-country to visit him.

The novel alternates between that trip and the sundering of her family. Hangâ€™s story has three centers of gravity; her almost inhumanly self-sacrificing mother, Que; her full-of-himself maternal uncle, Chinh; and her paternal aunt, Tam. Her family being torn asunder by those centers began when her maternal uncle, a soldier who had returned from the war and became a local political leader, turned on her father on the grounds that the latter came from a landlord family and forced her mother to denounce him. The uncle is in charge of local political discipline during a disastrous period of land reform after the end of what the Vietnamese called the American War. When policies are changed and the uncle is disgraced, the villageâ€™s enmity focuses on the mother.

Chinhâ€™s nature is revealed early on when he complains to his sister about her meeting with Tam, her sister-in-law. Although ostensibly an issue of political rectitude, he then complains about the impact it could have on his career. He does this a few times. Hanâ€™s reaction to that is to blame herself for not raising him right (she was the elder sibling); nothing that Chinh does shakes that loyalty. When he falls on harder times, she devotes herself to his children even above Hang, which causes one of the main conflicts of the plot. Part of that choice is because of her issue with Hangâ€™s relationship with Tam.

The embitterment of Tam against Chinh (and to some extent Que) because of what he did to her brother is balanced out by an attempt to claim the loyalty of Hang. Tam, despite having been deprived of everything as a class enemy, was able to work her way back up to a measure of prosperity and takes Hang under her wing, supporting her financially and exhorting her to make the most of herself. Since Tam is childless and Hang her only siblingâ€™s only child, Tam regards Hang as her familyâ€™s last gasp.

The characterizations are vivid and well-drawn. Although Queâ€™s self-sacrifice could have seemed unreal in the hands of a less skilled author, the portrayal of the mix of wanting to hold on to her remaining family and her resentment of the influence on Tam makes her tendency to accord a higher priority to Chinhâ€™s children not unrealistic. Tamâ€™s story shows her indomitable will and one almost gets the sense that her anger at what had been done her family had much to do with keeping her going.

Even the minor characters are well-drawn. For example, the portraits of the people promoted as political commissars in the village who were no-accounts prior to their promotion have back stories that are rich and engaging.

Very evocative Vietnamese novel about a young woman and her relationship with her mother and aunt. Woven in are past of old wrongs enacted during the revolution, the dodgy Communist party uncle, working as labour in a Russian labour, the superstitions and dramas of village life and the need to move on. Revenge and forgiveness are themes here but there are no easy answers or dramatic reconciliations. Vietnamese food & ritual is depicted in loving detail.

The amount that I loved this book was amazing to me. I mean, it was summer reading. I have to write an essay on it and everything. I practically HAVE to hate it. But I didn't.

Huong's writing is so rich and descriptive that you are literally transported to the Vietnamese villages she speaks of, to the old train rattling through the cold Russian landscape, to the empty Communist cities, and to the busy, crowded streets of Hanoi. I have never read a book so rich in cultural description before, which perhaps shows that I lack as a reader, but also shows how utterly amazing the writing is in this book. It is obvious that Huong loves her country, and mourns for what has been lost during the Communist regime. Yet she still celebrates the rich culture of Vietnam, particularly through her reverent descriptions of the food. While I was reading this book, I was constantly craving Pho, because she kept talking about it, describing the smell, the voice of the vendor, the taste of the broth. The food was as much a part of the story as the people themselves.

One of my friends was complaining about how there isn't any real story in this book. And yeah, I have to admit, it isn't the most exciting thing I've ever read. It's about life. A girl's life, written in memories as she rides on a train to visit her sick uncle. She is in a country where she feels utterly alienated. Her memories are dripping with nostalgia. OF COURSE it isn't nonstop action. The fact that it isn't makes you--or at least it made me--appreciate the descriptions and the characters more.

And the story definitely had its share of pain, sorrow, horror and heartbreak. It's about a Communism and starving people. What do you expect? But it also had its share of hope, triumph, love and joy. I thought it was balanced enough. Like I said before, it was very human. Which was good.

So yeah. Should have hated it. Loved it. Will now face the stigma of my classmates for actually liking a book we HAVE to read. But it's definitely worth it. (less)

In this beautiful, lyrical, and haunting novel about family relationships and what it means to be "home", Huong raises the question, is blood really thicker than water? While the author does engage some of the political issues plaguing a post-war Vietnam trying to redefine itself, she does not preach but rather tells the story of gifted, tragic, sad, and alienated individuals. I did not expect this to be a page-turner, but Huong swept me off my feet with her gorgeously poetic descriptions of setting--from the small enchanting Vietnamese village of Hang's Aunt Tam to her mother's hut in the slums of Hanoi, to Moscow in the dead of winter. This book was like my very own magical carpet--lush, concrete, sensual, heartbreaking--and just the kind of escape I was craving. I couldn't put it down. The translation by Phan Huy Duong and Nina McPherson was exquisite. Here's an example:

"On my first winter day in Russia, I had stayed awake for six hours, just to watch my first snowfall. It was freezing, but I stayed glued to the window, watching these strange flowers flood the earth with their icy whiteness. Light sparked off them in blinding shards, frail and luminous as a childhood dream. This beauty pierced my soul like sadness. Extremes have always wounded me...The snow fell to an unfamiliar, foreign earth. Beauty knows no frontiers, seduces without discrimination. The snow spilled onto the earth as if the sky had welled over with flowers" (Huong, 82-83).

This reminded me (a native New Orleanian) of the first snowfall I witnessed at the age of 21 in St. Louis, Missouri one night. Huong captures perfectly that feeling of enchantment and wonder I experienced. Beautiful book!

This book, written by a Vietnamese Woman and translated to English by Phan Huy Duong and Nina McPerson, is set in Vietnam and Russia after the Vietnam War with the U.S. and tells the story of Hang, her mother and her paternal aunt and through them tells the story of Vietnam after the war and the emergence of communism. This story starts in Russia where Hang is working as an exported worker in a textile plant and is told in a series of flashbacks in Hangs life. We see Hang as a young girl with her single parent mother wondering about her father. She meets her paternal aunt. Later she meets her maternal uncle and his family. Hang's mother is at first devoted to her daughter but then becomes devoted to her brother's children and spends all she has in her life for them. I would recommend this book to anyone interested in reading women authors of different languages and cultures. (less)

I read this book as part of my research on Vietnam and found it painted a desolate picture of life under the fledgling communist government in the early days after the French lost the country in 1954, and after the American War. Having said that, the detail of ordinary lives is fascinating: the food, the proverbs, the homes, the clothes, the beautiful countryside. The descriptions of food bring home how hard it was for people to survive, and how shocking the deprivation they faced. She builds a picture of a resilient people who during the 20th Century faced a series of wars that tore their country apart. The main characterâ€™s self-sacrificing mother is a street vendor, Hang is a student, and their lives are driven by the pursuit of survival against almost impossible odds. You can only admire their spirit and at the same time realise how spoilt we in the west have become. To suffer as they have and rebuild as they are doing now is an amazing testament to the Vietnamese people. As research it was terrifically useful, especially the chapters that deal with the terrifying land reform campaigns 1953-1956, but for me it didnâ€™t enthral as a novel. Although it is beautifully written and very strong on atmosphere it does read rather like a memoir. (less)

Story of two families connected by marriage but separated by status in Vietnamâ€™s communist system after the American war, with some history dating back to the French war. Itâ€™s told by the daughter/niece of the conflicted families, now working in Russia as an â€œexported worker,â€ who depicts the cultural and personal changes and losses under the regime, which has failed to bring material benefits, social justice, or corruption-free rule despite its military and political victories. First published in Vietnam in 1988 during an interlude of open expression, it was then banned (and the author expelled from the Communist Party, after 20-plus years of military service and party membership) for its condemnation of the failure of the system at the expense of the weak (which reminded me a bit of Steinbeck). 'Paradise of the Blind' is the riveting tale of a Vietnam torn apart by the communistic regimes of society. Set in the 1980s, the novel follows the life of a disciplined and resilient young woman named Hang who works in a Soviet Union textile factory to support her declining mother. The story is narrated through Hang's memories as she recalls her experiences growing up in the slums of Hanoi. Duong Thu Huong writes about the struggles of three, ineluctably related women: Hang who longs to know more about her father; her selfless mother who wants nothing more than to please her abusive brother; and the mysterious Aunt Tam who fights for her niece's better future. With its breathtaking descriptions of Vietnamese culture, this is the tale of three women fighting for their identities in an oppressive society. Despite its initial tendencies for uneventfulness, 'Paradise of the Blind' quickly begins to spark interest in its readers by providing a unique insight in to a previously unseen Vietnam. With an emotional story and powerful message, this book is a delight to behold. (less)

Casey suggested I read this book which she was required to read for this coming school year. It was a very interesting glimpse of life in Vietnam. It tells the story of three women: Hang, her mother and her aunt. Hang's mother's life is changed forever when her brother, a member of the government, enforces the new law stripping land from landowners and giving it to those who have no land. The ensuing shaming that is done forces Her father to run away. He ends up taking his own life. So, Hang and her mother are left to fend for themselves. Hang's aunt becomes her benefactor which causes her mother to withdraw her love and affection from Hang.

The point, I think, of the title is when you choose to be blind to what is really happening around you, there is a simple happiness whose root is ignorance. Do you choose ignorant, simple, surface-level understanding? Or, do you choose a deeper level of knowledge which leads to complicated happiness? Hang chooses the latter. (less)

Hang is a young Vietnamese woman working as an "exported garment maker" in Russia, trying to make money to send back to her family. As we hear of her modern day travails, coping with the cold winters and the cold attitudes of the Russian urban landscape, we also hear her history. Her mother was left to bring Hang up alone, after her father who came from a family of landowners was forced to leave. Her wealthy Aunt Tam tries to persuade Hang to get an education and better herself, but her ties to her family keep getting in the way.

It's an emotional and shocking book, and I can't quite believe how recent the history is. As far as I can tell, it's still banned in Vietnam, due to the political views the author portrays. Which is strange - there's no real criticism of communism as a dogma, but more the human story of power, corruption, and false hope.

It's a very simple telling of what is, in fact, quite a masterful novel. Enjoyable and thought provoking on many levels. (less)

Finally a book about Vietnam that's not obsessed with the American war. One of the final statements of the book sums up this book fairly well "Forgive me, my aunt: I'm going to sell this house and leave all this behind. We can honor the wishes of the dead with a few flowers on a grave somewhere. I can't squander my life tending these faded flowers, these shadows, the legacy of past crimes." (less)

I read this book for school. It is a gorgeously written piece that explores the life of a Vietnamese woman torn between her mother and her aunt. She is truly imprisoned by her world influenced by Communism and family ties. It is a valuable insight into Vietnamese culture as well as a criticism of 1980s Vietnam.

Fascinating insight into Vietnam that you never would get from a westerner (or even Vietnamese immigrants). From a western point of view I found the relationship of the Mother with her brother very frustrating, but then so did the protagonist. The way food was integrated into every scene was really telling of the important role food plays in their lives.

This book was (another!) school book and while I went in to it with the mindset that I wouldn't like it, that quickly changed. I actually did enjoy this book and would give it a 3.5 star rating, if I had the option to.
The book was about Hang and her life in Vietnam, struggling through family issues. Great literary novel. (less)

Hang lives in a world caught between her mother and aunt. Meanwhile, her mother dotes upon a brother who killed Hang's father. Sounds confusing, but this novel opens one's eyes to the importance of family, food, and respect in Vietnamese culture. A few parts of the novel confused me a bit, but for the most part, it was a beautiful novel about a strong young woman. (less)

One of my favorite reads so far this year. Duong Thu Huong reveals the experience of a Vietnamese girl and the war between her family, her duty, and her independent identity. The novel also presents an interesting evaluation of the communist movement in Vietnam and how exactly it affected the people.

A beautifully written story about Hang, a young woman who has moved from Vietnam to the U.S. With her mother. Much of the story is about her acclimation to the U.S., her relationship with her mother, and the "pull" between the two worlds. Dying Thu Huong writes insightful descriptions of sacrifices, family, hope and struggles with cultural differences. (less)
Interested in Vietnam, great food descriptions
students

Steeped in sadness, this book filled is nevertheless filled with sensual details about food and other Vietnamese customs. It's a heart-rending indictment of how Communism tore apart families in Vietnam and terrified neighbors until they turned on each other. (less)

Powerful book about a family in Vietnam during the 1970s-80s. I think the translation was a bit off - and had me purposely on edge throughout reading it. However, the story is intense. Learned a lot about Vietnam as well.

I enjoyed this book for the rich picture it painted of a culture I knew virtually nothing about. It's politically charged, to be sure, and old and new ways often struggled to coexist.
Interesting facts about the Vietnam of not too long ago, the poeple, culture, food and family expectations.

Three women of different era trying to figure out how to live their life. This is a literature from Vietnam. This novel also describes not only the life of a communist but also the victims, the oppressed and oppressors, and the unknown.

Beautiful, intense, difficult. I will be re-reading this novel because I think I missed a lot on first reading. But it is already fixed in my mind, the places, the scents, the tastes. And the fear. Incredible actually that I am so affected having felt that I need to check back!

An engaging book about Vietnam, seen through the changing relationships within a family. Beautifully written, giving an opportunity to learn abou the cultural and social life in the country

Gorgeous read. The language was beautiful. I enjoyed learning about Vietnam before the war, and how communism affected the peasant farmers and landowners as it took hold.

Well, this book is truly a wonder. After this, I promise myself I will try and read all of Vu Trong Phung's works one day. He deserves that truly special place in my heart. I still find it hard to believe all his novels had been finished by the time he reached the age of 27. He easily broke through the facade and the reached the depth of the human soul in ways that seem unimaginable.

I'm not gonna go into the little details of the story again. However, this novel in particular is completely hauting in the sense that it forces each reader to face a question of his/her own morality: What would I do and what would I become after I win the jackpot lottery? Will I be morally corrupted like the main character? Will I be able to resist the power of money, fame and fortune? I don't think anyboy can confidently give an answer right away to such questions. You can't say for sure until it happen to you. It's very easy to judge people but you never know what you will do once you are in their shoes.

I don't think Vu Trong Phung is at all a pessimist who only tried to paint an extremely negative picture of humanity. All he did was being raw, honest and courageous enough to look deep inside ourselves, forcing us to face questions and realities about ourselves we don't dare to face. (less)

It's hard to be kind when you are hungry all the time.

Nam Cao did not only point out this reality but he also prescribed his remedy which I would disagree. It is because he doesn't live in a society where hunger and thirst are no longer a problem and we all have much to consume. However even in that society, the noble wishes of Thu - the main character, have still yet come true. Material privation is just one reason for people to be less decent but it's not the only reason. People have free will and they even risk their well-being to practice that free will. In this respect, I would consider Dostoyevski's works are still much stronger.

But still, this novel is brilliant. I like the way the author laid out each character's psyche without doing it at length. A lot of the time I can sympathize with their sentiments and I even have much in common with Thu. The novel is short, about 300 pages long so it doesn't make me overwhelmed like some others.

One thing I found annoying is that it contains an ideology that I am not a fan. This ideology kind of reduces the power of this novel and gives a taste of propaganda. Perhaps I should not blame Nam Can so much since he didn't live long to see the future which nihilism is quite common in a more affluent society in comparison to his society. (less)

We might look at it this way: one of the areas of life from which female voices are sorely absent is the war front. There are relatively few soldierly memoirs, fictionalised or otherwise, by women. Duong Thu Huong fought in the war she describes, yet she chooses to take the perspective of a man, Quan, who is living in the blur of transitions from young to middle-aged, from idealism to disillusionment through the dark tunnel of a long, grinding conflict.

Initially I was disappointed by her decision, but very quickly I realised that I was wrong to be, since she brings to Quan's perspective a focus that runs counter to the notions of masculinity, particularly as imagined through military conflict, in my culture, emphasising the web of personal, deeply felt connections with family, friends old and new in his sorrow-stained world, his deep capacity for empathy and his susceptibility to communion with the landscape and reflection on emotional relationships, interpersonal and between people and land, nation and political movements. The result is a moody, moving, curiously light novel, in which constant sorrow like tirelessly falling rain is balanced by the warmth of friendship and sensuousness. If you hate war literature, perhaps try this anyway.

What made me feel a sustaining comfort in reading this was that the relationships between soldiers everywhere is one of deep trust - how important this is! When Quan is lost in a wooded valley, a dead man's spirit calls to him knowing he can help; the spirit trusts him and he can be trusted. When he almost dies of starvation and heatstroke, a child is able to revive him with produce from the land; young rice porridge, honey, tea made from the same herbs the soldiers use for camouflage. The land is on the side of its children.

Bien, Quan's old friend, mad in a pile of filth, is healed and sane the moment his friend comes for him. Quan returns to his home village. He remembers his mother with love, has none for his father. Yet he draws strength from deep roots in community. Gifts speak kindly. Age is counted from conception 'the first year in the belly'. Roots! Quan dreams often of his village, another life 'no one can step in two streams at once' the war is 'indescribably beautiful', so that he fears he will not know how to live in peace. And I trust him...

Quan is so pleasant, gently, kind, caring, humane. A fellow soldier, Hung, is his psychopathic alter-ego. Quan understands him, fears him, recognises in Hung's lack of it what makes him who he is: the love of others and for others. Many of his duties are pleasant for wherever he goes he takes pleasure in people and in helping them, and he remains inexhaustibly sensitive to beauty and emotion. He laments loss and death with genuine grief, mourning men and their talents, feeling the anguish of mothers and fathers and sweethearts; no violence is numbly witnessed here, every blow and cut and pang raises a response, a wound. Quan's talent is clear; he is a poet, even if he writes no verses.

This is a novel of such warmth it makes murder unthinkable. War is an outrage against a spirit like Quan's, yet bitterly he goes on, dreaming layers of his own past, warming to joy in sweet sunlight and in the pleasures of food and talk and memory.

One late dream visitation is an unknown ancestor who weeps for him, has an enigmatic message that Quan rejects in irritation and confusion. This encounter coincides with Quans disillusionment at the hands of a younger soldier, the most significant development in his character. In the light of this, the 'wraith's' comment about 'triumphal arches' takes on a new meaning I think. Quan mixes up his ancestor's urging with the Party's mythology; both seem to be trying to extract life and effort from the people in the name of worthless, illusory glory. But when the image of the Party shatters, Quan will have to find a new meaning for the words and tears of the ghost: what triumph can he and his comrades really reach? What arching legacy would he bestow, given the choice? It's his coming to maturity that makes this question urgent, yet leaves it open.

The text's meandering, cycling, flat structure mirrors the monotony of the long conflict. There are no climaxes; even the fabular omen of the lynx brings undramatised suffering and death. Hardship and grief are as much the substance of daily life as rice and shrimp sauce. Quan's dreams offer a shift in tone to high flown and emotive language, but the tedium of attritional conflict evoked by Quan's plodding quests is not reflected in readerly boredom. As Quan labours through landscapes of irresistable, soul-nourishing (though often melancholic) beauty, so the reader is led along a channel of sweetness and sadness that compels empathy, attention, hunger for the next day, the next journey, the next dream. As Quan finds the strength to live, I grew stronger myself. I found his relationships crowding into my heart. Every interaction had, I felt, an ease and tenderness totally absent in my culture from all but the tightest sibling bonds. If my people are to make ourselves whole, I thought, we must learn to speak to each other like this. Perhaps it's just me. My brother knows how.

I have been thinking critically about the violence in the language of book reviews and the synopsis of this edition here is a case in point. I was not pierced or shattered by this book, rather I was embraced by it, engulfed if you must, but gently: a sister grasped my hand while she told me a necessary tale in her kind, sorrow roughened voice. She helped me to see and hear what I had lived blind and deaf to, and I thank her and wish her peace. (less)

Lovesick doves cooed all day in the bamboo. Grasshoppers flew in the grass on the edge of the dikes. Women laughed, teasing and chasing one another, rolling in the rice fields. They made us laugh...There was once a kite that dipped and swayed in the blue of the sky, our dreams reeling in the same space...And there is the earth, this mud where the flesh rots, where eyes decompose. These arms, these legs that crunch in the jaws of the boars. The souls ulcerated and foul from killing, the bodies so starved for tenderness that they haunt stables in search of pleasure. There is this gangrene that eats at the heart...
This is the first book I've read that is wholly concerned with the Vietnam War. It was likely simple procrastination that birthed the mission to have my first literature experience set in complete opposition to the mythos of the US, the endless me me me of protests and veterans and yet another tale of isolated invaders making a far away country their Agent Orange playground of honored atrocity. People suffered, yes, people died, yes, but these people could escape. Those who feel I'm belittling, look at the wealth of white-gaze narratives and monuments and politics on one end. Then make your way over.
Orangutans are almost human. There's no tastier flesh.
One, the author was a Viá»‡t cá»™ng, before whom the United States fell to its knees. Two, the author is a woman, one of three survivors of forty after setting off at twenty years of age, and the first scene is of female bodies with the remains of breasts and genitals strewn around their worm-ridden corpses. Three, none of this matters, but such a rare perspective does deserve our full attention.
It's like dreaming. That's what it's like when you plunge into a forest. You can call and scream all you like; no one can hear you.
Bear in mind that this is the story of a winner. Bear in mind at all times that this is the story of a soldier whose hope has bred with their despair for far too long. Always remember that this is just one of the usual youths plumped up by the idealogues for the slaughter, for whom it took ten years of mishaps of death and decay on a nightmare landscape to reach the nickname of 'Chief' and the insanity to show for it.
Fighting and dying; two acts, the same indescribable beauty of the war.
Suddenly I remembered my mother's savage, heartrending cry, her face bathed in sweat, the horrible spasm that had disfigured her, and then, on that same, horribly twisted face, the radiance of the smile born with a child's cry, when she saw his tiny red legs beat the air...Barbaric beauty of life, of creation. It had slipped away, dissolved in the myriad memories of childhood.
I was seized with terror. No one can bathe in two different streams at the same time. Me, my friends, we had lived this war for too long, steeped ourselves for too long in the beauty of all its moments of fire and blood. Would it still be possible, one day, for us to go back, to rediscover our roots, the beauty of creation, the rapture of a peaceful life?
Fortunately for us, there is a mercy the soul of someone utterly sick with blood spilled for an ideal, and so we don't mind being enmeshed in the memorial swamp of this "gook" as much. Or perhaps we do, for we don't want to hear of forbearance of raping out of concern for the eventual danger of pregnant labor, we don't want to know about what horrors of flora and fauna will be birthed out of a healthy sprinkling of mortar and military grade herbicide, we don't want to see the blonde-haired blue-eyed as an unnatural invader after all this respect and courage and love of the other side, a side with its own measure of brave people and unfeeling corruption. You don't need Communism for an all but (are you sure?) Soylent Green extraction of the many by the few. You just need humanity, greed, their inherent love for lies, all of them ubiquitous, all of them wherever you may lay your weary head.
"Everything we've paid for with our blood belongs to the people."
Kha just laughed. "Ah, but do the people really exist?...You see, the people, they do exist from time to time, but they're only a shadow. When they need rice, the people are the buffalo that pulls the plow. When they need soldiers, they cover the people with armor, put guns in the people's hands. When all is said and done, at the festivals, when it comes time for the banquets, they put the people on an alter, and feed them incense and ashes. But the real food, that's always for them."
We haven't even touched upon the redemption and the fever craze, the insipidness of mortal circumstances and the graveyard leech of military success, the postcolonial inheritance of cannibal ideals and the retributional maw of time, what happens when everything is said and done and the pieces expect to be picked up. But you can find out for yourself.
Revolution, like love, blooms and then withers. But revolution rots much faster than love, 'comrade.'

The war for national unification--one hesitates to call it liberation, since the bulk of the novel takes place after the Americans have withdrawn--narrated by a Northern veteran. Quan, having enlisted as a patriotic eighteen year old, reflects on the changes that ten years of war and violence has inflicted on his country and his life. He finds many of the same issues that the American soldiers experienced during their service and after their return: a self-serving command structure blinded by ideology, post-traumatic stress, friendly fire, and, most devastating of all, loss of faith. Sent on a mission to his village, a family shattered, a loved one beyond estrangement. But this is Quan's own country, so survival does not lead to escape, and winning is not triumphant: even as it drives toward victory, the North deploys a lonely woman whose only job is to gather the corpses of its soldiers and a brigade for the sole task of making coffins. The prose of Duong Thu Huong, the justly celebrated Vietnamese novelist, is (at least in this translation) spare and unsentimental, as befits a soldier who is moving, to borrow the title of one of her other novels, beyond illusions. And yet there are moments where the prose, for all its devastating clarity, pierces: "'Don't breathe a word--to anyone. These days relatives spy against relatives, like jackals. Even their faces have changed. These aren't human faces anymore,'" Quan is told. Later he tells one of his soldiers, "'I am afraid there is going to come a time when no one will want to say anything to anyone anymore...'" And "Later in life, I learned that all the petty treacheries and crimes between people happen like that, seeping into relationships as easily as rain passes through straw." It is one thing for a writer to take up her country's pride in its struggle, but only the greatest can show it as a nightmare, that pushes a decent person, Quan, to the edge of what is human. But not beyond. (less)

"If, if."

Like all war novels, Duong's Novel is both horrifying and weirdly moving, just as they should be. War is awful in and of itself, but its effects on the people involved, even if not in combat (but especially those) is worse because they linger long after the battles have been fought.
In Quan's case, he's been fighting for ten years (the novel seems to take place in the final year of the American phase of the war, 1975), seen lots of friends die, but still keeps pushing on. Sent by one childhood friend, now an officer, to help another childhood friend feigning insanity (or is he?), Quan wanders across North Vietnam and then some, returning to his home village on leave and wandering through his own memories of what was and what was lost.
Beautifully written and completely lacking any narrative backbone, read: plot, save for sorrowful tangents here and there, it's mostly the story of war's splinters that you can't pry out no matter how hard you try. (less)

I don't think I've ever read a war novel, other than The Red Badge of Courage, and that was only because it was required reading for school. It simply does not interest me. But here I thought I'd give this one a chance, since it was written by a Vietnamese woman, i.e. not your typical war novel writer.
â€œAll [Hoang] had left was one arm, one leg, and a diary filled with gilded dreams. I remember ripping the [Communist] Party newspaper into shreds and throwing them into a stream. I never told anyone, of course. It was then that I realized that lies are common currency among men, and that the most virtuous are those who have no scruples about resorting to them. Since then, I've stopped reading newspapers, let alone bulletins from the front. I understood how those who didn't know this still felt joy, just as I understand their lust for victories, their fervor for drawing lines between true and false. Blindness gave them such extraordinary energy.â€
When we join Quan, the narrator, he's already a broken man, already seen way too much. He's already telling his men things they want to hear while knowing in his heart the dark truth. From there, the novel is a series of hazy episodes, not novelistic at all in that there was no story arc--but this I found to be a strength. At first I was not sure what to make of the title Novel Without a Name. But then I realized that a name is an attachment. Once you name something, a pet, a baby, a vehicle, you start to get attached. Perhaps the name of this novel without a name is just thatâ€“an attempt to not be human. An attempt to distance oneself from the emotions that we would otherwise feel if we were human. This was a good book. Don't let the mediocre star rating fool you, I enjoyed it more than I think I could have enjoyed any war novel. (less)

Why I think this might be the finest piece of Vietnam War fiction I've ever read, even better than the fine accounts given by Tim O'Brien and Bao Ninh, and a ready rival to that of Denis Johnson.

Most American art tends to describe the Vietnam War in gruff plainspeak (The Things They Carried, The Deer Hunter) or fractured psychedelia (Apocalypse Now, Full Metal Jacket, Tree of Smoke), Vietnamese writers take a different tack altogether. Vietnam might have been the war that signaled the end of America's age of innocence, but it was the war that defined the very existence of the Vietnamese nation. For an entire nation to be colonized, cut in half along Cold War lines, and then bathed in blood for two decades, well, that does things to a culture.

Quan, the protagonist, is honest and cynical and deathly afraid and wandering the ravaged hills of Vietnam, trying to reconcile the lyrical, village world of his childhood with the world he inhabits. And, unlike the Americans, for him there is not even the hope of an escape route. (less)

We've all, I'm sure, seen plenty of anti-Vietnam movies - Apocalypse Now, Platoon, Full Metal Jacket, The Deer Hunter. But how many of us have experienced a piece of art that told Vietnam's story from the Vietnamese perspective? Duong Thu Huong seeks to give the country a voice with this novel, and oh does she succeed in the most horrifying way imaginable.

This novel is often compared with All Quiet on the Western Front, and like that novel, this is a largely unstructured and plotless novel, to fit alongside the idea of war as a dull, grueling thing. It isn't even divided into chapters, preferring instead to take the form of several brief episodes ranging in length from a few paragraphs to a few pages. Throughout these episodes, emphasis is placed on the complete debasement and loss of innocence the war has wreaked on those who fight it. Much is made throughout the novel of fighting the war for the sake of glory, but there isn't much glory to be found here.

So that's one reason for me to love this novel. I hate the idea of war, and can only think of three even remotely justifiable wars America has participated in: World War II is obvious, and I see both the American Revolution and the Civil War as inevitable; even then, I'm convinced America committed a few crimes over the course of the Second World War (the atomic bomb springs to mind) that don't fully bear out our reputation as the glorious heroes of that war. What pushes this novel up to the top for me, besides it matching with my own beliefs and several beautiful passages ("On the banks the lush green foliage gently rippled. The paddles lapped monotonously at the water, in cadence") is the treatment of the characters. With the minimal physical description they're offered and the emphasis on their past, they seem to appear and disappear like ghosts, resulting in several fascinating exchanges about ideology and the nature of war. Check this out. (less)

The primary events of this novel take place in the last year of the conflict between North and South Vietnam. Itâ€™s important to distinguish that from the â€œVietnam Warâ€ which is specific to the US intervention into the conflict, a conflict which preceded our intervention by a great number of years, and continued for another two years after the Paris Peace Accord was signed. Further, it is important to note that this novel is specifically and distinctly Vietnamese â€“ with one brief exception â€“ the Americans (all Westerners) are long gone by the events of this novel, and are basically never mentioned, even in the flashbacks. In the West the Vietnam War remains a major touchpoint of the 20th century, while here, in the context of a decades long conflict that tore a country apart, itâ€™s not worth a mention.

In many ways this reads like a standard war narrative; setting aside some cultural specifics, large passages of this novel could be read and interpreted to be about many other battles and wars. There is a universality to the proceedings, to the fears, to the anguish, to the long interminable grind of war that ties this into the long and storied tradition of the war novel. And yet, again, it is deeply personal and specific to the Vietnamese perspective. There is a long stretch where the protagonist travels across the country, ruminating over his 10 years of war, running into friends and acquaintances of his childhood and early war days, and eventually returning home. In this we are privy to the destruction and depravation â€“ of infrastructure, of families, of philosophy, of culture â€“ that decades of war inflicts.

More than anything though, even with that focus on the high level destruction, the book is intimately focused on the psychological impact of war, of the constant assault on the psyche, and the loss of youth and innocence â€“ as a society and as an individual â€“ that cannot be reclaimed.

Most of the war novels I have read have been written from an American perspective. The ability to explore a non-American view of the Vietnam war was something I didn't want to pass up.

Reading Novel Without a Name was like walking through a dream. The world the author crafted was so surreally beautiful, and yet undeniably haunting. Many of the evocative images will stay with me; the soldiers sleeping in coffins to avoid tigers for example. Though described in lilting, lovely detail by Duong Thu Huong, the fact that death is still lurking for these soldiers in this time of vulnerability grounds the reader.

The appeal of this book for me was originally getting to read a new perspective on the Vietnam war. This novel did this, but I was also stuck by the similarities that the author draws between the soldiers on both sides of the conflict; there is a scene near the end of the book of an interrogation between the main character, Quan, and a South Vietnamese prisoner. Quan and the reader are brought to an unsettling realization about the realities of war and the people who fight in it.

Overall, I thought the writing in this book was decidedly beautiful, and I appreciated the opportunity to experience reading a book that was different from other war novels I have, and yet, oddly reminiscent in terms of the themes and ideas that are presented. I would recommend it. (less)

Set in Vietnam in 1975, on the verge of South Vietnam's capitulation to the north, Novel Without a Name is narrated by a North Vietnamese soldier who has been fighting for ten years. His round-trip journey to the north and back to the front for the final push, on his first leave, is both a love song of the country and its pre-colonial history, and an indictment of what the war has wrought on the people Quan has known or meets: his best friend's humiliation that after ten years he is still a sergeant, his childhood sweetheart who was recruited as a "comfort girl" for the higher echelons, his observation of two Communist officials laughing at the people they govern, the hunger and homelessness of the population, the cynicism of the men he leads.

A deep rumination on the far-reaching effects of war, and a searing indictment of ideological totalitarianism, Novel Without a Name is one of the great war novels of our time, even if the actual fighting takes place almost entirely â€œoff screenâ€. The story here follows a veteran NVA soldier, Quan, in the waning days of the war as he travels home, and later back to the front. In precise yet beautiful prose, Duong Thu Huong invites us to bear witness to the devastations (physical, psychological, cultural, and spiritual) of war, as well as Quanâ€™s growing disillusionment with the regime for which he fights. In this way Novel Without a Name isnâ€™t just a novel about the Vietnam war, but rather about all war everywhere. While Quanâ€™s experiences are unique to him and the war in which he fights, his emotional journey is universal. And that is what makes this book such a profound and important piece of literature. Told from the perspective of a North Vietnamese soldier, this novel provides a very different view of the conflict. The people disdainfully referred to as gooks in Matterhorn are revealed as human beings: sensitive, callous, conflicted, corrupt, caring. Duong Thus Huong was a leader of a volunteer collective during the war and was one of just three (out of 40) to survive. While she is a woman, Novel Without a Name is told from a male perspective. Duong Thus Huongâ€™s books were highly praised, but banned in her own country after she was imprisoned for spreading â€œstate secretsâ€ which amounted to her having smuggled this novel along with other works to the west. Duong Thu Huong became a critic of the war and an advocate for human rights. While her books are not published in Vietnam, she resides in Hanoi. (less)

I read this book back to back with Tim O'Brien's brilliant 'The Things They Carried'. Both paint a portrait of the war in Vietnam from a soldier's perspective.
In this case Quan is a VietCong who has spent 10 brutal years fighting. The book tells the story of a journey home to try to save a childhood friend. The journey is very much a journey into his own past and the effect of the war on him and all those he knew. It is also a poignant tale of loss and disillusionment but told without romanticising. No punches are pulled which makes it an excellent counterpoint to O'Brien's book.
Well worth reading, especially it you plan to visit Vietnam. (less)
readers of fiction -- especially those who enjoy translated fiction.

Iâ€™ve had this book since the late 90s and never got around to reading it. Iâ€™m glad that I did though. Better late than never!

My thoughts:
Plot - enveloping and thick. Journey of a young Vietnamese man who joins the war bright-eyed and bushy-tailed but ends up looking like roadkill. A wonderful commentary on the spoils and savagery of war.

Prose - Wonderfully translated although I did have trouble following at times. It doesnâ€™t follow your typical chapters and that can bother some people (to each their own). However, I enjoyed the Duong Thu Houng described the jungle in all its imperfections. If you really focused on the writing, you swear you could feel mosquitoes and ants crawling over you and that you were in the middle of a sweltering jungle.

Historical fiction of sorts that is a welcome change of pace from the non-fiction Iâ€™d been reading. Recommended, especially if you want a unique perspective on Vietnam. (less)

A novel about the Vietnam War from the point of view of a Vietnamese soldier. Although the war is all around, most of the novel is about its secondary effects -- the loss of young men, the damage to families and communities, the damage to the moral fabric of society. When a battle happens, it's over in just a few sentences unlike every other novel I've ever read about war. The author does not dwell on what happens in the battles; she's more concerned about the aftereffects and the other things going on. I'd have given it more stars but found it a bit hard to follow and hard to get emotionally invested. (less)

Growing up and living in America as a the son of Vietnamese refugees, I can't honestly say I ever fully understood (or even partially understood) what the perspective of the Northern soldiers were in the Vietnam War. Huong's novel gives a very honest, sobering, and so so gorgeous depiction of one soldier's view of it.

It's a lyrical and meandering tale of a soldier's disillusionment with the very ideals that thrusted him and his nation into war. I can't recommend this book enough for anyone interested in a really fresh look at old, deep issues of conflict, disenchantment, nihilism, and--somehow--hope in the face of war and destruction. Had I reviewed this right after I read it I would probably have given it three stars, because this book is less plot heavy and I didn't have a feeling of being completely sucked into the story, but as I get further away from this book I like it more and more. The story and the main character has stayed with me and I feel myself coming back to this book again and again in both conversation and in my mind. (less)

Intense, grim, yet not as depressing as I feared. This novel exposed the contradictions and futilities of war, and I still felt like everyone in it was a human being. I prefer stories with a bit more of a plot, but maybe that was the point here, the war itself had so little direction. This was a strangely refreshing read.

I really just don't know about this book. I really enjoyed the image and the pace was good but there's just so much in it to unpack. Definitely gotta have a highlighter at hand!

I liked I really did but it left me with more questions then answers in the end. (less)

At bit a hard to follow (admittedly, there was wine involved), this book was outstanding. Gritty, well written, and from a perspective I'd never thought I'd read about. Highly recommend reading (and in my case, re-reading) this novel. (less)

Wanted to like this book very much but struggled with it--there didn't seem to be a cohesive plot, the narration tended to be vague, confusing, and, to be honest, boring. At times it was very good but that wasn't often. (less)

Narrated from a Viet Cong captain's point of view, the story is episodic, but not quite a coming of age story. Quan, already disillusioned by the Party's slogans and propaganda, plods along to fulfill his duty to country and his childhood friends. (less)

This is an electrifying piece of literature. It's author manages to become a narrator, who she of course could at most have known. It feels like an old Roman Fleuve. Beautiful. Stunning. Lyrical. And a beautiful translation from Viet. Read it. (less)
had me tearing up within the first few pages...
The tragedy of war as seen by a young vietcong.
Authentic and vivid imageries of war time Vietnam.

Vietnam veterans
